reviewText:
First off, do not go into Clear Sky if you haven't at least played Shadow of Chernobyl first.

I'll begin with my overall opinion of CS. It's inferior compared to SoC, and especially inferior compared to CoP. The Faction Wars system, one of the main selling points to CS, is confusing at best. You can side with three different factions in each area of the game (though you automatically side with one by default at the beginning), and then certain factions become hostile towards you. In return, you get the chance to earn extra jobs and top-tier equipment earlier than normal. The only problem is when you have to actually fight the opposing factions. You need to travel to certain areas of the map, take out any resistance you encounter there, and wait for backup to arrive. In addition, if any of those areas come under attack, you're expected to show up and help out. Thus, you sometimes wind up with scenarios where you're halfway across the map, and get a call from a lone survivor armed with a shotgun to high-tail it over to their position and kindly take out the group of seven guys all armed with military-grade automatic rifles, please. The worst part is that your opposing factions don't stay dead. I've captured every single point including the main base, and killed everyone I possibly could, and they just respawn the second you leave. The good news is, while you will still have to help your allies out, you still get paid a substantial amount of cash for taking out the main base, so it's not all bad, I suppose.

Without a doubt, the worst part of CS is the enemy AI. For the most part, it's the same as SoC, except for the fact that these enemies can use grenades. Even on lower difficulties, you'll be tapping the quicksave button every few kills just in case they decide to spontaneously send an entire squads' worth of grenades next to your feet. Even worse is the fact that the AI is ungodly accurate with those grenades. Wherever they throw them, they end up directly at your feet with a one-second fuse. It's not at all uncommon to watch an enemy throw a grenade in the wrong direction (as in, they're facing away from you), only to see it reverse directions in mid-air and teleport right next to you. This is especially bad on the final mission, where enemies literally spawn from nowhere armed with automatics loaded with armor-piercing rounds and grenades primed and ready. The most common thing I found myself looking for in CS was not ammo, or artifacts, or even money, as opposed to SoC. No, it was bandages and medkits to replenish any health I was losing from unfair grenades. If you're playing through on higher difficulties, your first priority is to find some armor that isn't completely terrible, and then stock up on as many healing items as you can. Otherwise, you most likely won't stand a chance.

If you're coming from SoC, you should know that the system for picking up artifacts is radically different than how it used to be. Where they used to be waiting on the ground in plain sight for you to just grab, they're now hidden in the centers of anomalies. You won't be able to grab an artifact unless you have your detector out (press the O button to pull the detector out, and press 2 to dual-weild it with your pistol), and unless the anomaly you're looking at happens to contain one. Most anomalies don't. Personally, I held off on artifact hunting until I got a better detector, but if you can deal with lots of trial-and-error and quicksaving, you're welcome to try.

Speaking of artifacts, not every piece of armor you find can actually equip them. For some, you need to take it to a person who can upgrade weapons and armor, and pray that they're capable of adding an artifact container or two. Thankfully, most armors can, although it will cost you a good amount of money, even more than upgrading a top-tier assault rifle. Speaking of upgrades, if you couldn't already tell, you can do that now. The same people who offer upgrades also repair your damaged weapons and armor (for a nominal fee, of course), sell you locations of stashes (which can also be found on dead bodies, although sometimes the person selling you a location will tell you what you can find before you open it), and offer you jobs which usually consist of find information on a particular upgrade in a stash somewhere and bring it back to me". Keep in mind that you still need to find the stash first

reviewText:
Head back into The Zone, taking on bandits and the military as you explore the environments from the first game. Sounds fun enough?

Well, the enjoyment you get from STALKER games is dependent on whether or not you're able to overlook and put up with all manner of errors, bugs and little idiosyncracies. I'm talking enemies with pistols turned into sniper rifles, a lack of healing items and grenades that land right at your feet from hundreds of feet away. These are amazingly atmospheric games and the worlds they have are so believable and well crafted it's just a shame that they quite often don't function the way they're supposed to.

Clear Sky is the black sheep of the series and by that I mean it's the game that most people agree is the weakest of the three. I still give this one a thumbs up because there really is nothing else like it and it is worth playing the entire trilogy if you're into them at all.

But this is still a deeply flawed game and you might want to check out some mods to get it running smoothly and make it a bit more forgiving.

Full video review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yDrXMQrclpY

reviewText: Catching up on my PC video gaming has been something of a spiritual journey for me. I have found my highs, my lows and then there has been a special place that doesn’t quite measure on the spectrum. S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Clear Sky seems to take that measurement system and throw it out the 10th storey window. I want to put it somewhere on the bar with the likes of Half-Life 2, but then no, it doesn’t quite add up. Whilst the game mechanics are very similar at times, I find myself comparing it more to Metro:2033… then again it often feels more like Fallout 3. There’s no denying it has similarities but doesn’t quite match any of them individually. The game has found a very small pocket within the genre to carve out its own place in game history as a deftly challenging, gritty & unique game. It combines elements of successful titles and throws them all together creating something new, inspiring, very challenging & brutal.\n\nIt is proof of truly evolved gaming that was made by gamers who have a great understanding of games & have refined it in a very Russian way. Cold, calculative & ultimately, brilliant.

reviewText:
Immersive & unsettling // Recommended for horror-survival enthusiasts looking for a challenge
*As I am reviewing the core product, and not various third-party mods, this review is based on a purely vanilla playthrough. Please keep that in mind, thank you!
+ Many locations and characters from Shadow of Chernobyl make a reappearance in this title
+ Equipment and weight limitations do much to force the optimization of one's gear, and make one choose what to discard and what to keep; this leaves the player feeling both challenged and rewarded as they acclimate to the concept
+ Artifacts add slight RPG-like stat combinations; these are more challenging to use than in the previous installment, though many will enjoy the increase in challenge
+ Very, very strong sense of atmosphere pervading throughout
+ Boasts a large and active modding community (many mods do well to address some of the game's various pitfalls)
+ Ambient sounds are absolutely fantastic, and keep the player consistently unsettled
+ Manner of interaction with various game-world NPCs is largely determined by the player's actions throughout the adventure; can join and help differing factions, netting different rewards (friendly factions will even show up occasionally if you're in a firefight, and they will aid you)
+ The game's world and atmosphere complements an intriguing plot; the story, itself, rewards inquisitiveness
+ Absolute plethora of side-missions
+ The game's environments are vast and very detailed; visuals, too, are crisp and the lighting mechanics excellent
+ Fast travel is included (for a fee, unfortunately)
+ Finding artifacts, as compared to the game's predecessor, is a new and unique challenge

- Lip syncronization is absolutely atrocious
- Hunger and thirst has been removed; some may view this as a positive, but as this series tends to attract the purists in the RPG community, most would likely see this as a negative
- Bullet mechanics can often be questionable in behavior
- Crouching, much like in the first installment, is laughable; one's character lowers by perhaps an inch, and it offers virtually no protection in any given situation

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements, and I also have a budding YouTube Channel for those interested. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
(**EDIT** I just finished the game, and lemme say, if you haven't played the first game, the ending will not make sense. Even if you have played the first game, the ending is not very satisfying. In my opinion, you should get your enjoyment out of the rest of the game, because there isn't much to be found at the end.)

Rough, somewhat broken, but with a little love is simply fantastic. It's atmosphere is unmatched, it draws you in like your character's body draws in radiation. Also, the voice acting is meh, but that's part of why we love STALKER.

Vanilla, the game has many glitches, ugly models and textures, super accurate and powerful enemies, innacurate and weak player weaponry, and questionable design decisions, but mods and a bit of technical know-how can turn this game into something beautiful. Well, maybe it's not visually beautiful how I run it, but I enjoyed it thoroughly nonetheless. I personally can recommend Clear Sky Complete mod, as well as The Road to Limansk. You can find both of those mods on the ModDB page for Clear Sky (Road to Limank says that it hasnt released yet; it has, just follow the links on the page).

Also, you should get STALKER: Lost Alpha, a free fan remake of Shadow of Chernobyl, with loads of lore-friendly added content. I never played SoC, so I can't compare the two, but hey, it's free. Also, be sure to get Boredgunner's Lost Alpha Mod Pack 2014, which updates all weapon models, animations and sounds, adds 50-ish new weapons, and tweaks the economy to be more fair in terms of pricing and item availability (among other things... check out his ModDB page at http://www.moddb.com/games/stalker/downloads/lost-alpha-mod-pack-2014) . I am having a blast playing Lost Alpha, and you should be playing it too!

reviewText:
Now, Part 2 of the revisions. To recap after the 1st stalker game revision....this is based on the vanilla experience.

Ah, the prequel. Also, the game that the stalker community thought was forgettable. Me? I personally LOVED this game. Sure, it's missing a few things....namely hunger, and an all-around creepiness with some of the environments. But to counter, this game introduced some features that proved to be worthwhile; for instance, the weapon and armor upgrades and repair. Do the weapons and armor still degrade? Yes, but now you can enhance them with more armor plates, flex the durability, and even add protection against anomalies. It's needed because if you ask me, this is the hardest of the 3 stalker games. Just as is with the first game, once you get to a certain point, there's no turning back. So, be prepared for ANY situation again.

The story revolves around Scar, a mercenary that inserts himself into the faction war. Various factions are battling for territory in the zone in a race to reach the center. When a group of stalkers reaches the center, the zone changes and becomes more unstable, making the territory more valuable.

Gameplay is relatively the same with a few changes. First, the artifacts aren't just there for the taking this time. You need a detector to find the artifacts, which involves getting into the thick of the anomaly. The weakest detectors won't spot the best artifacts, so you need a top notch one to make up for the weaker ones shortcomings. This game also manages to feel less like a sandbox, only because as you progress through the story you are able to uncover more of the map. In other words, you're actually blocked from progressing far into the zone until you progress through the story. Once you get so far, then it's open for you to explore all over. Numerous players weren't fond of this because of the open nature of the 1st game, but i think it worked well here because it made for better pacing. You couldn't get the best weapon in the game very early, giving you a major advantage. Even the armor suits were paced better, as an exoskeleton suit COULD be given to you about half way through, but required some work on your part in joining the faction wars for Duty or Freedom. Better pacing equals more fun if you ask me. The stalker way is the hard way.

Artifacts were not so abundant here, as each map in the zone contained a few anomalies, which hold artifacts. With less artifacts comes less money, which means upgrading or repairing was a little tricky because you had to draw the line between keeping an artifact or trading it in for a valuable upgrade. Less money also equals more fun. Stalker games are supposed to be challenging and this adds another layer of challenge. Of course, once you get so far and have your armor or weapons upgraded, then you can save some money for future use.

The AI has some improvements, but still has its pros and cons. The faction wars can be a bit buggy sometimes, as the AI isn't entirely supportive. You may find yourself doing alot of the work, and while this game is difficult as it is, i personally don't mind doing most of the work. It's a shooter.....you shoot things. The more the merrier.

Most of the maps are reused from Shadow of Chernobyl, with the addition of a few new ones. The swamps and red forest are the highlights, creating a fresh change from gloomy landscapes to lush vegetation. Also, some of the reoccurring maps have been slightly altered to appear more lifelike. Remember, this takes place before the events of SoC.

All in all, i think this game gets a bad rap. What it is missing from other stalker games it makes up for by introducing some iconic stalker features, like the upgrades. Again, mods are a-plenty here, but do yourself a favor and play vanilla first...on MASTER difficulty. It's brutal again, and the difficulty spike is worse this time around in the end, so be even more prepared. While it still may not be every stalker fan's cup of tea, it's still part of the stalker lore that every fan should check out. It's my personal favorite of the 3 games, mostly for the reasons of the pacing and balance. Difficult as hell, borderline rage-inducing in the end, but still worthwhile. Crowning achievement completing this on master. Good luck stalker.

9.2/10

reviewText:
Lots of good reviews on this game already so no need for me to spill much ink on the vanilla game.

Shortly i consider this the weakest game in the series - yet it's still head over shoulders better than many other more known FPS games. It's gritty world is unique and i have always had fond memories of this game series  (minus the endings for Clear Sky and Pripyat)... But no more on that.

So why do i play this? I play this because of TFW mod (The Faction Wars) - Few know about this awesome mod that gives you a ton of gameplay by removing the story and remaking the world to support factions. It's a free world now yet the area is so familar.

In this mod you start out as a loner without any equipment and it's up to you to try to survive. You'll need to eat, sleep and get paid. but that can be hard as there are no freebies in this game contrary to vanilla game. stashes are looted. corpses get looted right after the fighting stops and if you try to grab stuff that someone thinks belong to them they will confront you. Needless to say early game is hard but VERY rewarding. Later you will start doing faction missions - or continue to be a loner. It doesn't matter much what you choose. Point is the options are endless and there are so many routes to choose and before you know it the most limiting factor is your actual free time to play the game. I am looking forward to 50 hours+ of quality game time from this mod alone that executes just right the way faction wars should be.

Here is a good place to start looking at mods that might tickle you the right way: http://cheeki.violates.me/

reviewText:
Can't believe I've never reviewed this game as the STALKER series is my favorite of all time.  It is recommended that you play Shadow of Chernobyl first, but not a must.  Although reguarded as the worst of the three, I still think it is a must play.  The beginning is slow and the ending is unfairly hard, with the everything in the middle being one of the most unique out of the three. Faction wars brings a whole new mechanic to the table. As long as you don't finish them completely off, one of the most immersive to me.  There are a few bugs in the game, and after finishing the vanilla game I played it with the STALKER Complete Mod.  This to me is a bugfix and not really a mod, since it really keeps the immersion of the vanilla game.

=Open world atmospheric thriller
=Side  quests and pda function more appropriately
=Improved map and Pda
=Weather is superb

The big downsdie to Clear Sky is the ending.  Yes there is a point of no return and if you are not prepared you may not be able to beat it. It is hard, ruthless and unforgiving.  Depending on your point of view you may be disappointed with the ending as well.  But in this game, its the journey, not exactly the ending that is memorable.

Still a 9.9/10, and a must play.

reviewText:
This review is for people who have played Shadow of Chernobyl.  It's about the single-player campaign, with the Complete mod.

I hope you liked the previous game, because you're essentially about to play it again.  Given that this one is a prequel, there are so many similarities in the environment (which is about 80% the same as the first) that you get a kind of wistful echo of adventures past (or rather, future).  It's a bit interesting to see what various parts of the zone were like before SoC.

You play as Scar, a merc who has survived emissions from the Zone for some unknown reason.  Once again you're chasing Strelok (really!?!).  The first time he entered the heart of the zone it set off an emission which was similar to a small cataclysm, setting all the factions against each other.  Your objective is to prevent him from doing it again, which would possibly produce a lethal emission killing everyone.

The new wrinkle this time is the faction system.  It's really just an extension of the old system, with some capture the flag type elements.  You can even take part in the initial war between Duty and Freedom this time around if you like.  Although the rewards are meager for this type of activity, it nonetheless makes the zone a far more dynamic place than it used to be, with NPC's shifting around constantly depending on who wins what fights.  Inconsequential, but you do get this vague sense that you have a hand in shaping the zone.

The combat system is still bull****.  I hope you weren't expecting any serious improvements.  Bullets still go wherever the **** they want, even with the Dragunov on occasion.  Enemy AI is just as bad, possibly a little worse (and that's with a patch to improve it!).  Even so, it is definitely satisfying getting the headshots with a scoped weapon.

This time around you can actually upgrade your weapons at various smiths, and find schematics to deliver to the appropriate npcs in order to get specific upgrades.  Kinda neat, and meant to extend the life of the game, but wholly unnecessary.  Same goes for your typical stash drops, which are now a part of NPC dialogues.  Fork over some dough for the information, and most of the time they'll tell you what's in it before you even leave camp.

You'll still reload frequently, but nowhere near as much or nearly as rage-inducing as the first game.

I can't testify as to how bad the final mission is (remember the last one on SoC?).  My game permanently crashed on all saves about two areas before the end, so I had to watch the ending on Youtube.  It was moderately unsatisfactory, and frankly I'm glad that I didn't have to worry about however bad the last mission was probably going to be.

A lot of other stuff is recycled.  The game looks a little better, but you can tell they didn't particularly try.  If you look at my play-time, I'm guessing it's about the same length as the first, maybe even a little shorter.  The shelf life was no doubt meant to be extended via multiplayer and dynamic zone faction wars.  This is Shadow of Chernobyl 1.5, essentially.  How much you liked the first game will directly determine if you like the second.

reviewText:
The second game in the series, but the first chronologically (being a prequel), this game is by far the most underrated of the series. 9/10, if you ask a S.T.A.L.K.E.R's least favorite game in the series... it's this one, it gets a lot of hate for the fact that on release it was very unoptimized and buggy and there really wasn't any workaround for it. But now, of course, like any other game in the series, a ton of mods are available for us to choose from and almost all of them include bug fixes and optimization features. Some of them stop there, upgrading the graphics a little, optimizing the game for you, and fixing common bugs and issues. Others, however, expand on the open faction system that this prequel provides. Unlike in Shadow of Chernobyl, this game allows you to interact openly and work with the factions outside of their main quest lines, going as far as joining them after reaching a certain status; and that's not just Duty and Freedom, that's almost any faction in the game.

The story, while not expanding too much on the events its predecessor, provide a little insight into what was going on in Shadow of Chernobyl and why it was happening, as well as revealing to you (Scar) information that Strelok did not know at the time. Don't get me wrong, Strelok is a cool guy, but Scar is probably my favorite character of the series. Either way, don't ignore this game because of earlier setbacks and whatnot, with the mods you have available now you can experience the game in almost a completely vanilla state (if you so wish) with all of the bugs and unoptimized mess fixed and cleaned up.

Again, an excellent series; the story, atmosphere, characters, and mod variety all make it worth its price. Tons of replayability to be had.

reviewText:
While this one was a big disappointment for many people, but there's no reason what so ever that this is not hell right worth the sweet $9.9 dollars.
Gameplay+ Fast-travel is now available.
+ Atmosphere is spot-on, from the start.
+ Overall map and mini-map are improved.
+ In term's of weapon's it feel's less twicthy.
+ Over 4 factions to choose from,all with pretty rewards.
+ Weapon's and armor have been made upgradable now.
+ Many more realism improvements add a good challenge.
+ Artifect's can't be found laying around now, you have to put more effort.

- Side-quests are mostly meh.
- Bugs,bugs and bugs ranging from A.i to crashes and more.
- Many armors and some weapons have been made inaccessible.
- Faction-war's are broken, many of the time's the squad or the enemies may not even arrive.
- Gun`s at times feel like you are using a toy gun,this is the case with many of them weapons.

Story+ It isn't so worse, pretty fine in my opinion that is.
+ It's well-placed, many scary and tide turning moments.
+ Voice-acting has improved and is best from the all the-three.

- Disappointing ending.
- It may seem pretty confusing for starters.
- Dialogue actually seems a bit odd at times.
- Many scripted moments where you don`t have much a choice.

Graphic's+ They sure have been improved from lighting to the texture's.
+ Model's are more better looking and npc clothing has been made more-cooler.

- Many micro-stutter's in between.
- Buggy and just plain bad animations.
- At time's the graphic's really show there age, from poorly textured wall's and bar's.
- Optimazation is a pretty bad factor here, many even high-end machine's may not be able to run at decent (high) setting's.


Design+ Just pure feeling of bitterness.
+ Many previous areas have been improved.

- Generic map design and corridors as the game progresses.

Sounds+Ost+ Ost gets the job done with it's bitterness.
+ Voice-acting has improved and is best from all the-three.
+ Overall sounds i think are really generally better from nature to weapons.

- Same reused menu-music.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Transactions and cut-scenes are nothing special and quite boring on the part, as well the whole game it feels as a chore as you are just being used and throwed around by literally everyone.

ConclusionIn all even though the countless amounts of bugs and roughness id say really get it if you havent played any of the s.t.a.l.k.e.r games then this one is more good for starters.

reviewText:
Stalker Shadow of Chernobyl (SoC) is one of my all-time favourite games I have played thus far – even made it as one of my top ten of all times. Blends with FPS, survival and a touch of role playing elements, it was brutal, yet enjoyable experience. So when I hear that the next Stalker game was on the horizon (instead of waiting for seven years), I couldn’t wait to see what GSC Game World have in store. Well, just a year later, along arrives Stalker, Clear Sky (CS) – a prequel to SoC and sadly, also a lessor game in most areas as the new features like Faction Wars just didn’t pan out effectively.

Like most open world games, it’s hard to say how long to beat it. For me, as I like to do literally everything and explore every nook and cranny, took me about 65 hours to complete, so I can safely assume average will be around 20 or so. Pretty decent with a good array of missions / side quests and diversions, CS is unfortunately a step down from SoC. The new features like Faction Wars and able to customise your weapons did not pan out well enough as actually, they are more of a hindrance or simply, not worth investing your time. However the emission blowout was pretty awesome due to its sudden nature. So if you are coming from SoC, expect to be disappointed however if this is your first Stalker game, it’s an enjoyable ride but expect spoilers. I guess you can view CS as a rock and a hard place.

Full review here: http://www.gamespot.com/s-t-a-l-k-e-r-clear-sky/user-reviews/2200-12643375/

7.5 / 10

reviewText: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky is a great post-apocalytpic game. It has an amazingly large world, full of mutants, and characters, and radiation, and whatever you can think of in a post-apocalyptic game. It has a great atmosphere that makes you feel like you're actually in the post-apocalyptic time period, and I recommend it. This game can be a little annoying sometimes, because of how challenging the combat is, and how hard it is to afford new weapons and supplies, but that only adds to the realism and atmosphere of a post-apocalyptic game. People say it's the worst out of the series, and if it is, the rest of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games must be amazing. It has a photo realistic world, and it's very fun to explore it. If you have ten dollars, you should definitely get this game.

reviewText: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky  Clear Sky is a good game however has a lot of shortcomings in optimization. The game can drag on for many hours of fun by performing the side missions. reviewText:
The atmosphere is great, as in any STALKER game, and things are up to the level of SoC and CoP for a while.

Until you decide to get involved in the faction wars (extremely bugged) or until you reach the last 25% of the story: then it's just a military shooter, where enemies will home their granades right between your eyes. Tons and tons of human enemies to kill, but the atmosphere is completely lost.
What made SoC and CoP great games was slowly passing though abandoned towns and desolated landscapes, looking for precious artifacts and watching your back from bloodsuckers and other mutants. If you want this in CS, you need to really force it upon the game.
On top of that, mind that most (all?) maps and locations are the same of SoC. I played SoC some 4/5 years ago and still got lots of deja vu. It can be nice, realising that you actually know this or that place, but feels a bit lazy somehow.

Overall, I recommend it to STALKER veterans who want a challenge, but perhaps CoP with mods is a better choice. In any case, do not forget to install the Sky Reclaimation Project to fix bugs and enhance the experience.
If you have never played a STALKER game, play Shadow of Chernobyl and Call of Prypjat first. Those are the real deal.

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: C̶l̶e̶a̶r Grenade Sky is canonically the first of the STALKER series, and also the most difficult entry in some regards. Of particular note is the fact that Bloodsuckers are invincible while invisible(whereas in Shadow of C̶h̶e̶r̶n̶o̶b̶y̶l Grenade they were still a pain to kill, but could be hurt no matter what phase it was in). If Call of P̶r̶i̶p̶y̶a̶t Grenade was the only STALKER you've played, then C̶l̶e̶a̶r Grenade Sky will serve as an unpleasant(or at least unexpected) surprise. For everyone else, you get to experience the mixed feelings that come from obsessively quicksaving before every major action and dying repeatedly to a̶n̶o̶m̶a̶l̶i̶e̶s grenades, r̶a̶d̶i̶a̶t̶i̶o̶n grenades, m̶u̶t̶a̶n̶t̶s grenades, b̶a̶n̶d̶i̶t̶s a noo cheeki breeki iv damke, and p̶s̶y̶c̶h̶i̶c̶ ̶a̶b̶o̶m̶i̶n̶a̶t̶i̶o̶n̶s blowouts. As with all of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games, an excellent quasi-survival sim of which a majority of its charm is derived from the unrelenting and completely unforgiving difficulty.

For those who want to know what Master difficulty is like, here is a very good example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GB7bi12VStw

Oh, did i mention the engine is hilariously glitchy and a great source of continued amusement?

reviewText: Despite this game's quirks and bugs (which are easily fixed by a good mod) it is quickly becoming my favourite game in the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series. The level of storytelling and lore is unmatched by the other two games in the series. It also gives you a glimpse into the early Zone and the faction war that ravaged it, allowing you to join a faction and bring about victory against your foes. Ignore the universal dislike this game suffers, it is a great game to play through for S.T.A.L.K.E.R. fans and those who've never played any of the series before.
voteText: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
You know, for a Prologue, It is not bad. It could have been better though.

The Gameplay, levels, and Characters are still here. They are just worn down slightly. But the difficulty curve goes to the highest level at the beginning, and gets much harder over time. You cannot survive more than a Couple Makarov bullets ripping through your flesh, but all the other enemies can survive so many rounds to the point that you are wasting your own ammo. Money is much harder to make, Medical supplies are impossible to find, but Ammo is so easy to find.

The story is slowly paced but very well performed and well written. AI is a mixed bag, Artifacts now require a detector to find, But this and all the other S.T.A.L.K.E.R entries are beautifully designed, immersive, and can be replayed over and over again.

I am glad this is $10 less tthan the other two because It is quite weaker actually. But I think this is better than Call of Pripyat.

THATS RIGHT.

This game hits more notes than CoP.

Might as well play this after you complete SHoC.

Overall: 7.9/10

reviewText:
Clear Sky is another fine entry in the STALKER series. Less intense than Shadow of Chernobyl (SOC); less claustrophobic, less scary. But all the incredible atmosphere of this genre-bending series is intact.

Impressively, compared to SOC, Clear Sky presents both a more linear main quest, and a more sandboxy world to explore.

There are some bugs in this game. The map for the city of Limansk... some people can't load games that are saved on this map, which makes it very difficult to complete the game. Because of the bugs, many people skip this title and move straight to Call of Pripyat.

To beat Limansk, I used the Wish Granter” feature that is included in the Stalker Complete mods to spawn myself some allies to help me through Limansk without saving. (More on the "Complete" mods in the comments below).

The STALKER series is one of PC gaming's finest. If you miss the complexity and subtlety that we used to enjoy before consoles got popular
date: you really should check these games out."

reviewText: Many say this is the worst S.T.A.L.K.E.R game. Well, for the worst game in the franchise, this game is amazingly addicting! First of all, if you enjoy survival games that are not cheap and full of gimmicks (I'm looking at you Dean) then you will most likely enjoy playing this game! Food, water, and radiation are all there to aid and tear you down as you march through The Zone! Encountering wild animals, dangerous humans, and seemingly other-worldly creatures keeps you on your toes at all times even in 2015! This was my first S.T.A.L.K.E.R game and it will NOT be my last!

reviewText: Ukrainian and Russian post-apocalyptic open world RPG/FPS taking place around a fictional second accident at Chernobyl. Like the other S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games, mod for best results. Clear Sky is the second game in the series and probably the least favored by the community because of it's bugginess. A strong addition though to the three titles Clear Sky takes players to the Zone before the events of Shadow of Chernobyl. Clear Sky's defining mechanic is faction wars, absent from the other two titles, it also features some new areas and some old but differently inhabited.

reviewText:
Personal review of: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky
Mods: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky Complete
Difficulty: Master


S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky is a sequel/prequel to the events prior to Shadow of Chernobyl. Taking place in 2011, where a second emission took place and created the Zone, a place filled with mutants, strange anomalies, and it's populated by STALKERS, basically scavengers/fighters/artifact seekers, you get the point. You play as Scar, a veteran STALKER chasing down Strelok when an emission hits and you are left incapacitated. You wake up at Clear Sky base, a swamp base where this faction is devoted to understanding the Zone and learning all it's secrets and uncovering the strange phenomens going on. After you finish a few tasks you are free to explore the Zone and side with whatever faction you want, explore and play the game. I won't say more than this since it took me 2,5 hours just to leave the Swamp areas (doing quests, exploring etc.), so the rest is up to you to find out. The game is built on the same X-Ray engine, with a few updated changes. Mainly the AI has been tweeked to fit the new faction war system, visuals have been upped, and many more changes have been implemented. As far as Stalker Clear Sky goes, almost all the weapons have been reused for this prequel, half of the areas too meaning you will revisit some familiar places while exploring new ones. Enemies, NPC's too, so you might find the actual content of this one a bit lacking. Onto more relevant changes, the HUD got reworked, being simplified, also the PDA got some new features, being able to track more easily your tasks, you can now see enemy/friendly factions on the radar, giving you a better understading of where they are being concentrated, etc. The hunger system has been removed, don't know why honestly, weapon upgrades are available, the way you collect/obtain artifacts has also been changed, to the point where you need to use an artifact detector to see" them. This also implies you will have to walk into the middle of anomalies and hope you won't get killed before you collect them. Stalker Clear Sky has received some flak

reviewText: Sim, Clear Sky beira o 'ruim' e o 'não tão bom quanto o SoC mas bom'. O jogo começa bem, open world como o primeiro, te dando opções pra completar as missões, escolha de facções pra uma faction war q parece interessante. Depois começa a frustração. O jogo se afunila e fica linear como um Call of Duty, matando qualquer tipo de exploração e uma ♥♥♥♥♥da de situações scriptadas. O faction war não funciona: você limpa e captura pontos, mas seus aliados não ocupam o local, e qdo vc sai os inimigos simplesmente voltam. Você então desiste do Faction War e foca na story line. Mesmo na dificuldade Normal, os inimigos conseguem te acertar mesmo q você esteja sem 1% do corpo a mostra - atras de cobertura. Conseguem dar tiros certeiros q tiram metade da sua vida. Pra piorar, sua armadura tem durabilidade e a única forma de consertar é com NPCs, e custa caro e nem sempre você tem acesso a eles, principalmente da metade pra frente do jogo, qdo vira um rollerscoaster. A última fase então é um ♥♥♥♥ fest: tem tempo limite"

reviewText: Personally i believe this is one of the best games ever due to how dynamic the gameplay is. If your into first person or any open world shooter this is the game for you. Not only is clear sky good but they have other games in the series such as shadow of Chernobyl or call of pripyat. The stalker series would of been amazing if they haven't of given up on the stalker 2 game but they did and now the licence was grabbed my bit composer, which is making the game survarium a look alike to the stalker series turned into a first person mmo shooter. Over all of this game i have to give it a 10/10. i don't want to be a graphic's ♥♥♥♥♥ but the game was made a while back so don't expect far cry or skyrim graphics.\n\nNow i'm going to go into the dynamics part of the game. The game is very immersive. you can spend around 1-5 hours on this game and get back to the real world like What just happened?" reviewText: Stalker has been considered by many a post-apocalyptic first person shooter game. But it isn't, your in a Cordon zone of the Chernobyl area that has been abandon since April of 1986 due to NPP4 catastrophic failure rendering the environment hazardous to live in. Yes, the place dose exists for real, all locations are based on real locations in the real zone. Life is still going on everyday for the people out side of the zone. The Stalker game series is inspired off the book Roadside Picnic"
date: which is a short science fiction novel written by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky in 1971. More information on this book is available on a wiki
recommended: and the book is also available in English now.  The game is a open world exploration as well as mission directive

reviewText:
(Before reading this review, read my review of stalker shadow of Chernobyl) http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197984765152/recommended/4500/
(And just like before I played this game on the highest difficulty and WITHOUT MODS, and don’t start whining at me saying you need to use mods)

Clear sky is a prequel and near the end happens at the same time as shadow of Chernobyl. In clear sky you play as a mercenary called Scar who is able to survive emissions and ends up working with the faction Clear sky, whose goal is to stop Strelok from reaching the middle of the zone where it is believed something catastrophic with happen.

Clear sky does add a few new things into the game since now you can upgrade and repair weapons and armour, artefacts are much rarer and you need a detector to find them, you now have guides who can take you into different places, you can side with most factions, you now need slots for artefacts and you must have a minus radiation value artefact if you have a plus radiation one to counter it otherwise you will slowly die of radiation poisoning, and the hunger and thirst system was removed so food now just acts as health items and energy drinks are just to boost your stamina, but other than that this is very much the same as shadow of Chernobyl.

Clear sky also improves a few things that were in shadow of Chernobyl, the map and PDA have been improved, most of the weapons are a bit more accurate than the previous game but they still aren’t great, moving is no longer headache inducing, and thankfully loading quick saves won’t cause the enemies to go back to their starting positions which can be right next to or in front or behind you and you'll get killed instantly.

This is still a strangely compelling game but it still comes with problems from the previous game and it adds its own.

The gunfights aren’t anywhere near as to what they were in the previous game but it is still a little random on whether you’ll get shot or not and the damage output.

The amount of bandages and med kits used to stop you from bleeding out is random to the point where sometimes it will only take one bandage, but other times you can go through all of the bandages and med kits in your inventory.

The map is incorrect with the directions used to go to this one area that’s south east of the red forest, you’d think you’d have to go to the exit pointing south east but that takes you to Garbage, you actually have to go to the NORTH exit point to get to the area that is SOUTH EAST of the red forest.

The height difference between standing and crouching is two or three inches.

Enemies can now throw grenades, they can throw grenades from over 100 yards away and they explode a second after they land and this is really annoying when you are trying to kill a group of enemies only to have a few grenades land at your feet.

Your weapons jam far too often.

Just like shadow of Chernobyl getting this game all comes down to whether you think you can put up with these problems and I actually enjoyed this a bit more than shadow of Chernobyl to a certain extent.

reviewText:
Clear Sky, in it's untouched state was unplayable for me until I installed the COMPLETE mod. At that point the game opened itself up to me, and I'm loving it nearly as much as SoC.

Like the original, it's initally unforgiving, with an excellent soundtrack and a seriously ominous and unnerving world. The map is improved to give the player more detail as to who is around them and what their function and intentions are, and the interactions between the different factions are a lot easier to interpret, which makes intervening and helping people out a lot easier.

You spend a bit of time re-treading old locations, which can be a bit disappointing. However, the areas are occupied by different factions with different goals and it's kind of nice to see how the area changed over time between this game and the SoC, to which Clear Sky is a prequel.

It also has some new graphical features, particularly when it comes to lighting, that really brings out some more polish in the game's visuals, and makes any action performed during nightime a terrifying affair.

This is not my favourite of the Stalker series - that remains SoC - but the world is still compelling and oppressive as balls, and the core mechanics are more refined than those of its predecessor, so it certainly is worthy of the player's attention after finishing SoC.

reviewText:
Although all 3 Stalker games are fantastic, Clear Sky is my favourite. It is the most atmospheric of the 3, the most challenging, the biggest (yes it IS bigger than Call of Pripyat), and has the best soundtrack.
Sadly it was also the buggiest at release and had some glichy cheating AI which coupled with the fairly high difficulty at the beginning put alot of people off. Everything been fixed up now more or less. It's still a tough game, especially the first few hours but put the time in and you will be rewarded with one of the all time great PC gaming experiences.

I recommend it!

reviewText:
I found Clear Sky more enjoyable than Shadow of Chernobyl myself. It's much more refined than SoC and when I moved it was a big breath of fresh air and looking back made SoC seem a bit more flawed than it was on the first play. Clear Sky was one of the first RPG orientated games I was able to complete, but looking back the startup was a bit rough. I can really compliment the sense of progression and direction of the game, as well as being a decent length and engaging enough to play the game til the end. It's not one of the best games i've played but definitely worth the purchase if the price drops down. Just promise yourself to play it, it's a more than decent game.


I also felt a lot less ripped off by the ending compared to SoC's true ending.

reviewText: I tend to think of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R games as Marmite games. People either can't stand it or they get addicted. Sure each and every stalker game has it's bugs. The gritty way the games play is brilliant though. It's an odd difficulty curve, starting off quite hard, getting easier and easier as you get better gear. That's probably the main thing that puts people off, it's a trial by fire. Make it to the point you start getting some nice gear and your all set. If you've played the original and liked it then give this a go!

reviewText:
The prequel of the game STALKER Shadow of Chernobyl.
The user starts as a mercenary named Scar who was found by the Clear Sky faction in The Swamps,unconscious ,after the most powerful emission The Zone ever did, near the bodies of some scientists that he was paid to lead. The character is a mercenary but is not part of the faction Mercenaries" and he was able to survive 2 emissions that affected his nervous system ( this leads to blurry moments during gameplay).The story takes place in The Zone and your task whether you like it or not is to help the Clear Sky faction find out who is messing with The Zone until The Zone turns every living beeing into ashes.

Clear Sky brings new dangerous areas with new quests

Artefacts aren't spread all over the map like in SoC and since they're produced by anomalies they can be found only in anomalies

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Clear Sky" - Review

Gameplay:  6/10
This second installment "Clear sky" leaves something to be desired. Some elements were indeed improved upon such as weapons: dynamics
date: upgrade-ability and inaccuracy. The use of image blurring also added more depth. This certainly made the game much more fun. A slightly larger world (even though some of it is lifted straight out of the first game) was just what it needed.These things worked well.\nThey've taken the game to an exciting new level by going deeper into the RPG genre (e.g. goods trading etc) which unfortunately has come at the expense of the 'first person shooter' gameplay
recommended:
and the game suffers for it. It's no-longer balanced; it simply doesn't flow as well as it's predecessor. Going from story to action feels like segments of contrived scenarios of RPG then FPS then RPG then FPS. Even though things happen in-game and around the map without me being there (living world) overall it leaves me feeling more like I'm being taken for a ride rather than being an integral part that sways the flow and outcome.
By half way into the game the shoot outs were predicable and by the end of the game the shooting scenes were frustrating unless you have upgraded armor and guns.
Initially it seems like a lesser game than the first one but it gets better the more you play it. It's not a bad game; if you can forgive it's minor short comings it can still be lots and lots of fun.

Game ambiance: 7/10
Standard S.T.A.L.K.E.R. ambiance which is nice as expected. Leaves
hoursPlayed: birds
voteText: rain
helpfulPercent:
wind and weather.

Reliability/Stability: 4/10
Installation was easy enough (both DVD and Steam versions) but in-game there quite a few bugs. Some around AI
votesHelpful:
the faction wars and some were graphics related. Stability hugely varies depending on the PC.

Story/Plot: 4/10
There were some new ideas expressed which were a lot of fun. However
votesTotal: once you strip away the faction wars and take a good look at the story there's not much there
votesFunny: the overall plot was weak and lacked depth which added to the games segregated feel.\nWhile there is a bit of a twist (if you can call it a twist... more like an interesting angle) i don't much care for it. All i can say without giving anything away is that I felt like all my work in the first S.T.A.L.K.E.R. game was done for nothing
commentsCount:
and then undone.

Concept: 8/10
I get the impression that at the beginning of the "clear sky" project the game developers had a good range of ideas
column16:
then somewhere along the line they got lost in what can only be described as a quagmire of loose ends and poorly finished tid-bits.

Concept execution: 6/10
Is should have been a well rounded
column17: a matured concept.\nFaction wars extend what could have been a short game into an epic one. The novelty of joining factions was fun initially but when it eventually looses it's luster you realise the only motivation for acquiring money in the first place is for weapons. Which is OK
column18:
big guns are cool.
The AI is a little better but buggy; rather than going around you the AI guys push you out of their way and straight into the line of fire.

Textures: 8/10
The textures were a great improvement on the first game. There is a warmer feel
column19:
they are more sharp and use some more modern features. Although the settings will have to by played with to get optimum results.
I love that the PC's in the game use Norton Commander.

Modelling: 7/10
There really weren't many new elements (most were from the first game). What it does have looks good though.

Graphics: 8/10
The graphics are a vast improvement; 'Clear sky' does blend each element better than the first game and it certainly added to the overall look and feel. Even though the draw distance could have been greater.
That being said
column20:
there could have been much more work done in the way of OOP. As on many systems there is a huge draw of resources for graphics that shouldn't require it.

Sound: 7/10
Sound too was an improvement compared to the first game. Clean
column22:
crisp.

Music: 5/10
The dynamics of the music was good even though the style was not my personal preference
column24:
it's art. There were some song elements that were from the first game and other songs that sound like songs from Mech Warrior: Mercenaries that didn't make the final cut.

Adjustable shadow mapping: No

Bonus/Extras:
Special edition comes with - Novel Book (Russian)
column33: random faction badge and a ball that lights up with S.T.A.L.K.E.R. on it."

reviewText:
I found Clear Sky more enjoyable than Shadow of Chernobyl myself. It's much more refined than SoC and when I moved it was a big breath of fresh air and looking back made SoC seem a bit more flawed than it was on the first play. Clear Sky was one of the first RPG orientated games I was able to complete, but looking back the startup was a bit rough. I can really compliment the sense of progression and direction of the game, as well as being a decent length and engaging enough to play the game til the end. It's not one of the best games i've played but definitely worth the purchase if the price drops down. Just promise yourself to play it, it's a more than decent game.


I also felt a lot less ripped off by the ending compared to SoC's true ending.

reviewText: I tend to think of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R games as Marmite games. People either can't stand it or they get addicted. Sure each and every stalker game has it's bugs. The gritty way the games play is brilliant though. It's an odd difficulty curve, starting off quite hard, getting easier and easier as you get better gear. That's probably the main thing that puts people off, it's a trial by fire. Make it to the point you start getting some nice gear and your all set. If you've played the original and liked it then give this a go!

reviewText:
The prequel of the game STALKER Shadow of Chernobyl.
The user starts as a mercenary named Scar who was found by the Clear Sky faction in The Swamps,unconscious ,after the most powerful emission The Zone ever did, near the bodies of some scientists that he was paid to lead. The character is a mercenary but is not part of the faction Mercenaries" and he was able to survive 2 emissions that affected his nervous system ( this leads to blurry moments during gameplay).The story takes place in The Zone and your task whether you like it or not is to help the Clear Sky faction find out who is messing with The Zone until The Zone turns every living beeing into ashes.

Clear Sky brings new dangerous areas with new quests
hoursPlayed: improvements to the graphics ( like dx10
voteText: sun shafts etc ) and gameplay.The user is now able to repair and modify equipment (guns and suits) with the help of data found on usb sticks ( the mechanics will ask for these for advanced changes) and join factions after helping them defeat their rivals but beware you are neutral to all {except monolith and some mercenaries} and taking part in their wars will set your status "at war" with the faction they're at war. Artefacts aren't spread all over the map like in SoC and since they're produced by anomalies they can be found only in anomalies
helpfulPercent:
invisible to the naked eye but visible with the help of detectors. Almost every settlement has a taxi that can lead you in places ( not everywhere) if you pay him.
The game opens the path for Stalker Shadow Of Chernobyl but doesn't give new info on The Zone.

Personally I recommend playing this as vanilla for a true STALKER experience then you can mod it and enjoy unexplored areas.

Pros
-Work for artefacs

Cons

reviewText:
I initially played the second STALKER game exclusively in Russian. I had the Ukranian collector's edition. I don't speak and can barely read cyrlic. But i beat the game. Does this say something negative? Probably, the story wasn't anything too interesting, feeling like a creation from a decision basedo on the success of ShoC.

The grenade bugs are frustrating, the endgame pales in comparison to ShoC, but the improved graphics and envrionmental story telling are incredible. Limansk is one of the most involving settings to any video game, and that cut content teleroom gives me the creeps.

Faction Wars is probably the best idea to happen to the series although its implementation is so-so. IT feels great rising through the imposed ranks, it doesn't feel good being told to help all these small patrols who seem to be attacked 24/7 and watching them die from kilometers away feels like forced drama.

8/10

reviewText:
Essential things to make the game playable:
-Accuracy mod: remove RNG accuracy.
-Antialiasing on DX10 and above set to 2x or downsample on your own; use SGSSAA on DX9 or an injection--SMAA (SweetFX) forces the game to DX9. So use eFX if you want DX10.
-God rays mod: it makes the game look awesome (and it didn't affect performance in my case).

Also, don't install Shaders max mod; it has a lot of compatiblity issues and it affects the performance negatively instead (as the mod author states that it affected half of the users).

Warning: I somehow like the game, but I am on the negative side. I am done with it at this point. I do enjoy obsecure games with meh gameplay, provided that they have other redeeming qualities, but gunplay in this game is simply bad.

Pros:
-Good atmosphere.
-Nice graphics.
-Great gameplay/survival elements.
-Factions and collecting artifacts.

Cons:
-Extremely bad gameplay.
-Badly optimized.
-Hypersensitive when it comes to modding.

Summary: Don't waste your time with this outdated, dysfunctional piece of crap. If you want to play it, install mods BEFOREHAND and WASTE a large amount of time. I really liked it at first and liked its aesthetics; I am simply disgusted at the fact that I wasted over 5 hours trying to get the damn game to work after installing a couple of mods, and trying to deal with the shooting mechanics. I am 10+ hours into the game and I will not restart just to install a mod that is essential to play the weakest entry in the series.

I will start with the most important thing in  video games: gameplay and how functional it is. Clear Sky is not only the weakest entry in the series (supposedly lacking in atmosphere but it is my first Stalker game), but it is utterly unplayable (once you start fighting things and shotguns miss at point blank range) and makes you wonder if the developers/game designers have been exposed to an excessive amount of radiation to even THINK of such game mechanics--the stupid RNG accuracy.

First and foremost, shots are based on RNG, which means you will miss 30ft shots and have to waste a magazine at least to land a SHOT; enemies have a huge amount of HP and they have absurd accuracy and aggro mechanics. I am obviously talking about the hardest difficulty in the game, but shooting is dysfunctional either way; the game is simply boring on lower difficulties. Also weapon jamming (RNGesus), bad maps/no cover when you attack a base, stealth doesn't work properly, FRIGGIN SWAY THAT LASTS HALF A SECOND WHEN YOU MOVE AND AIM, slow aim, slow weapon switching, slow reload...etc. The combat is ****.

With that said, you HAVE to install mods in order to have fun on normal difficulties or something functional on the highest difficulties, which brings us to how crappy is the game when it comes to modding. You will spend hours just troubleshooting and figuring out in the end that there is some shader incompatibilty or some crappy dll file missing. And the worst of all is having to restart a new game when you install an overhaul or other types of mods.

Another point is the optimization and lack of a proper Antialiasing. The latter completely destroys the performance when you max out the game on DX10.1. I ended up with a much better game that runs on high frame rate and looks good with godrays  mod, but jaggies and transparent object edges are there; 2x is the most subtle option. Trying to use SMAA or FXAA injections means you have to use DX9, so good luck making a decision there.

The good point is that the game does feel and look atmospheric, but the combat is an utter piece of crap. The best course of action is to play CoP or SoC (if you can bear with wasting time trying to mod that crap).

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky

It has been a while since I last played it, but after noticing some updates for some mods I used to play and the lack of a review, I decided to write this.

Anyway... What can I say? An aweful lot, but I'm going to keep it short. This review will touch on two aspects of the game; modded and unmodded.

Modded
I'm recommending this game because of mods. The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series is among the most moddable game series out there. Despite this game being the weakest in the series, mods can quickly turn it into one of the strongest, if not the strongest. I've put more hours into this than I have into say, Shadow of Chernobyl or even Call of Pripyat (though between Misery and the recent release of Call of Chernobyl for CoP, my CoP playtime is catching up.

Why? Simple really. A single mod called 'The Faction War' or TFW for short. It takes a wonderful mechanic brought into the series (but removed for some reason in CoP) and turns it into something more. What might this feature be? Faction wars, of course.

Join one of the many factions and fight for supremacy, or go alone in the zone and fend for yourself against mutants, bandits or any factions you decide you don't like. It turns the game into an RTS of a sort, with reasonably large scale firefights - or, if you want to, quiet night-time operations.

Unmodded
The game is good without mods, but it is arguably the weakest in the series. It has an number of bugs which can be fixed through the use of mods and community patches. Other mods serve to enhance the story and gameplay, so by now you're getting the picture. You can play through the game fine, but you'll end up turning to mods to enhance, fix or even overhaul the game.

I'll go into more detail another time, so for now this'll have to do.

reviewText:
The lowest quality of all of the stalkers. The game is clearly influenced heavily by call of duty, which was released just before this. The vanilla game crashes a lot, enemies are quite powerful and grenade spam is common. Bugs are extremely common, and the level design is quite poor.

Some of the freedom of approach is deliberately limited for no reason. For example, in one instance a machine gunner is immune to bullets until you can get behind him and shoot him, even if you have a sniper rifle and can already hit him in the head.

Most of the changes to gameplay are negative, and you will be spending most of the time desperately managing your bleeding.

However, it does add a lot more to the story than call of pripyat.

reviewText: Due to some flooding and my terrible internet, I ended up playing this game in offline mode. It's an okay game, but a decent entry into the series. This game is a prequel to Shadow of Cernobyl. Clear Sky contains the entirety of Shadow of Chernobyl's map, with two new zones included; however, this makes playing the game seem like more of an expansion than a standalone title. Clear Sky lacks the pacing that was present in the first title. Within 10 minutes you're loaded up with a pistol, assault rifle, ammo, and medkits. Compared to Shadow of Chernobyl, this game is a lot more action oriented. I finished the campaign with about 650 Stalker/Military/Faction kills, and 100 mutant kills. With so many kills, the gameplay began to feel a bit stale. My favorite part about Clear Sky was seeing how my actions affected the future game. I recommend playing Shadow of Chernobyl first, and following up with this game for the backstory. Overall, I would suggest you skip this title unless you are a big fan of the series; although, I highly recommend the first game.

reviewText:
After reading some reviews of this online and hearing about the many bugs CS has i bought it anyway and i am glad about my purchase, so here is a review of one of my favorite survival games.

Gameplay- Now when i started i didn't know the controls and i didn't even know i had a headlamp on my first playthrough (This ♥♥♥♥ed me over at night, try navigating with nothing but the glow of your ECHO locator.) and i do wish they had a little tutorial like Shadow of chernobyl had because there we're times where they told me things and i didn't even know what the item was or how to equipt it like the bolt. I had heard about a ton of bugs in the game but i didn't encounter them i think the only bug i had was later in the game i was about to go to CPP and i had to go do some small quests first, well a emission hit and i got stuck and kept dying so what i did was i used my sleeping bag i got from the mod i had (CS Complete) and i slept through it, afterwards every trigger was broken and i had to reload my save to get enemys to spawn or triggers to work and such.

Graphics- A lot of people will say the graphics are ♥♥♥♥ and aren't very shiney and new, well i feel that actually adds to the game because while playing newer games like Payday 2 some of the graphics would cause problems with aiming or trying to see a target, while in this i don't have those fancy lens flares or whatever getting in my way while trying to shoot a enemy from far away,

Story- The story is kind of ♥♥♥♥, i love it and all but i just can't get into it, it is hard to follow sometimes and some missions just have these massive walls of text, don't get me wrong i love games that have a good story and such but it is like mass effect it has so much text that it just kind of slows the game down and makes me want to take a nap and stop playing. Now i don't want to spoil it so i won't really speak about the mission or the ending but i will tell you that you want to stock up before going through red forest because there are a lot of high paying missions in there that you don't want to fail.

Well if you read through my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ review that i probably ♥♥♥♥ed up in many parts congrats now you get to see some numbers!

I give S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Clear sky a 8.1/10 great game but some things just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off and didn't make me enjoy the game as much.

reviewText: By far the weakest of the STALKER. games, Clear Sky is still a solid FPS/RPG hybrid, with suprisingly intelligent AI (and surprisingly inconsistent too), which makes for some great firefights.  And I hope you like firefights, because with this game's focus on factions of human NPCs, rather than the mutants, radiation, psychology horror, and physics bending anomalies of Shadow of Chernobyl, you'll do a lot of man-shooting.\n\nDefinitely a different take on the STALKER experience, and far from a failure, it still lacks the amazingly alien atmosphere of desolate loneliness and creeping fear of the first game. Luckily it was followed up by another entry, which combined the best elements of its predecessors...

reviewText: In the second installation of the wonderful S.T.A.L.K.E.R. franchise you play a mercenary named Scar. Clear Sky takes place one year prior to the events in the first game. In this prequel, you not only learn about Strelok's past, but you also discover that before settling in The Zone, all of your enemies were participants in the NFL. Becoming quite nostalgic about their past in the world of sports, these said individuals recreate their days on the football field with live grenades.

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Clear Sky is a direct prequel to Shadow of Chernobyl and it's events shed some more light on what went on before SoC and why stuff happened the way it happened. The Zone is also way less of a hostile place in terms of enviorments. The early areas even seem like a cool place to hang out for any man, and the weather is simply splendid from time to time.

The fact that this game takes place before SoC also means some gameplay-wise changes. For example; the artifacts the Stalkers are after are way less common. This means that you'll actually have to hunt for them now, making you actually feel like you're doing what SoC told you Stalkers do: they *hunt* for artifacts. The artifacts themselves also have been redone in terms of bonuses they provide. I actually found myself selling them for quick cash in SoC all the time, while in Clear Sky they are actually useful to keep on your person for their bonuses. Some absorb radiation, others provide bonuses to healing regeneration over time.

But this is not the only gameplay change, far from it. Due to the massive Zone-Emission at the start of the game, the clans of people in the Zone have gone at war with each other, using the confusion of the Emission as a good reason to take over new territory. Each of these factions are joinable by the player, and come with terrain the faction wishes to defend or capture. For the player this means they can engage (when they want) in capture or defense missions of certain locations, often bringing them rewards, and greater rewards for capturing bases. As they do this, the influence of their faction increases, while that of the enemy faction decreases.

Another change is found in AI behaviour, which is (especially on Master) a lot trickier than in SoC. No more wall hugging enemies that are easy to pick off with a sniper rifle. No more ♥♥♥♥♥ that will run into your gun; people are actually clever now. If they try to sneak up on you and you spot them, they'll take off and find cover, to shoot you in formation.

Other than these changes, there's numerous other small tweaks and changes, ranging from stalkers that will take you to specific places in the Zone (for a price of course) to the ability to upgrade and maintain weapons and armor, and then I haven't even mentioned the whole -BLOWOUT SOON FELLOW STALKER- part.


Then there's locations to visit. Clear Sky mostly borrows it's locations from SoC, even letting the player visit them in the same order SoC made them visit them in. However, some new areas have been added, some old areas removed and some areas have been changed slightly, or have been added more locations to than in SoC. Still, it's mostly the same ♥♥♥♥ you've been through before. This isn't a bad thing per say! After all, the Zone is the Zone and they try to base it on the real Exclusion-Zone in Ukrain, so they did a good job at how they did it.

The thing mostly changed about locations that were re-used, is by filling them up with bases of the factions. For example, the Duty faction has it's base at the Agroprom Research Institute, while that was an abandoned bunch of offices in SoC. They actually made proper use of such empty locations this time around, and that was fun.


However, the endgame is absolutely horrible. The last hour is filled with bugged AI, terrible game design and is just horrificly stupid. The game decides it's a good idea for you to shoot a running target over a long walkway. This walkway is interrupted by several teleports which teleport you to locations where you have to finish off certain enemies only to progress to the next teleport. Not only is this insanely out of place, it's also badly programmed and build in at the most unlogical time possibe. A massive downside.



Overall I'm giving this one an 8/10

reviewText:
7/10
Overview: First Person Shooter

Note: I used the complete mod to play the game.

The Good:

+ Once again atmosphere is the main selling point of the game. The setting, locations and realistic art style really showcase the destruction of the Chernobyl incident.  The developers really nailed being in a destroyed post apocalyptic nuclear death zone. Buildings are crumbling and dilapidated, broken vehicles litter the roads, small settlements of makeshift homes and building house some of the other inhabitants on the 'zone'. Every aspect of the game facilitates you feeling like you need to survive. With the updated engine, the game looks even better than before

+ lighting effects

+ A new addition is factions. You can join a faction to gain unique quests or help them out in general. Joining one faction usually puts you at odds with another. You can choose not to join anybody.

+ Another new addition is the upgrade system. Different armors/weapons have different upgrades that you can choose to buy making them more powerful/effective in combat. In order to unlock certain upgrades you first have to find the blueprints, usually found in stashes or given as quests rewards.

+ Side Quests have been improved somewhat over the first game. Money and quest rewards are more valuable than before and the quests are a bit more varied. Completing quests feels more meaningful.

+ Game play is nearly identical to the first game. Gameplay consists of killing enemies as you traverse 'the zone', scavenging dead bodies and loot to find weapons, armor, ammo, health etc. Survival is a main underlying component with the game. Weapons and armor degrade over time making them less effective and need to be fixed or replaced, radiation levels have to be checked, getting shot or attacked by mutant animals require you to use bandages to stop bleeding, eating is required every so often and you also need to watch your weight limit. Carry too much and your stamina runs out very quickly forcing you to stop or walk until you regain it back.

+ Gun battles are fun, fast and furious. Certain main missions puts you in unique situations which makes gun fights more fun and satisfying. Certain battles reminded me heavily of Half Life 2. For example one mission has you making your way across a deserted town as you clear the road of enemies. Unlike the first game where gun fights usually took place as you traverse the open environment to your next objective, Clear Sky has more focused concise battles tailored to the specific level.

+Variety of different weapons that feel unique

+Sound Effects


The Average:

With the addition of Factions also comes brain dead AI companions. Like most games, when you go into battle with your teammates, you will do the majority of killing while your 'teammates' sit back and relax. Teammates can also push you aside with ease - a big problem if your aiming down sights ready to make the crucial head shot only to have one of your squad member run into you pushing you aside messing up your aim.


The game features most of the same location as the first game with a few new additions. It doesn't hurt the game by any means as the locations and level design is fantastic however I also find it a bit lazy when developers heavily reuse assets from the previous game.

Long load times.

Minor bugs and glitches.


The Bad:

- (Minor spoiler Alert) There is a part near the middle of the game where you lose all your money without warning. From a story perspective it makes sense, this is a hostile environment and anything can go bad at any minute. From a gameplay perspective this is awful. All the work that went into saving your money so that you can eventually buy your favorite piece of armor or weapon is now gone. Not only was I frustrated but my desire to accomplish any more side quests was also diminished.

-Locating artifacts is a chore and almost unnecessary in this game. Artifacts are items that you can equip that grant you specific bonuses to your stats. In order to actually find these artifacts, you have to first equip your detector, than walk around the level in the hopes it will detect something for you to find. I found the process to be  time consuming and boring. This was a big downgrade from the previous game.

- This game is hard even on the medium setting. Right from the start enemies can kill you with relative ease leading to some very frustrating moments causing me to abuse quick save/load.


Conclusion

Although the game certainly retains a lot of good things from the first game while improving on certain aspects, the overall package is not as good. The pacing and difficulty being the biggest culprits. The addition of factions is a really good idea but not implemented as well as it should have been.  I enjoyed my time with the game but I was glad it was over.

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R : Clear Sky

Très bon OpenWorld pour un prix de 10€ !!!
Beaucoup de choix et de diversité !
Très grande map et un design post-apo presque parfait !
Certain détails génants sur le jeu.
Si je devais noter :

Graphisme (7/10)  // C'est pas le plus important
Gameplay (8.5/10) // Très bon gameplay pour un post-apo
Histoire (8.5/10) // Simple , mais sympa
I.A (6/10) // J'ai vue mieu , mais c'est plutôt bien
MAP (7.5/10) // Très grande map , et magnifique mais remplis de bug.

Good Points :
-Il est possible de choisir sa faction ou de se faire un status envers certaine factions (Allié , neutre , enemis)
-Les combats continues , même quand vous n'êtes plus à coter ou même dans la zone
-Bonne ambience
-Bon système de trade
-Hardcore (pour les hardcore gamer)

Bad Points :
-Les alliés te pousse quand tu es sur leur position (limite il te mette dans le viseur enemis)
-Votre arme est enrailler

reviewText:
You know one of those games that might seem like a knock off but does a good job? This is one of those games.

I've spent over 75 hours in the game and I am about to go throguh another run at it again soon and boy oh boy, I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game. It's rough around the edges in difficulty and smooth in story, a nice touch to the game itself since most of them now a days are either microtransactions or lacking content.

Overall punch-line: Think of Fallout, now add Metro and picture a baby - this is that baby / this is that bread for your PP&J / This is that couch that always eats your change, only finding that change when you really need it / this is like that one really good drink you ordered at the bar and forgot what it was called but rediscover it two years later and call it sex in a glass / This is a damn good game in other words.

I am only at the part where im about to head into Dark Valley, and ive been enjoying the game a ton. Defintely reccomend for anyone who enjoys open world, roleplaying, survival, shooting, and vodka. reviewText:
I've played S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Clear Sky just after discovering Shadow of Tchernobyl.

Except some improvements in the rendering engine (mostly lighting) and the interface (HUD and Inventory), the gameplay is mostly the same, so you won't be lost in this new opus.

The most important element of gameplay provided here is the Mechanic guy, who can repair and upgrade your equipment (armor, weapons). Being able to customize your gear early really add to the game.

In spite of this, I encountered a huge difficulty wall after cleaning the swamp". After emerging from a huge pipe
date: I'm confronted with about 20 soldiers and a huge machinegun. This was a halt for me and I never succeeded in exploring what the game had to offer.\n\nI didn't like it because I played leisurely in easy mode (that was hard enough for me). I would have accepted it after like 4 to 5h of play
hoursPlayed: when you emerge inside the soldier camp !\n\nSo in spite of its qualities
voteText: I really cannot recommend this game who doesn't want to be played even in easy mode."

reviewText:
5/10, crappy end game. If you're new to Stalker series, play SoC or Call of Pripyat.

Clear Sky has it's moments. There are lots of well designed environments for geocaching. Day/night cycles highlight game's excellent shadow system. Anomaly artifacts are rare enough. Game works a lot like Shadow of Chernobyl in most aspects.

On down side, some missions aren't that much fun on harder difficulty levels, there is little or no benefits from finding hidden caches, Faction Wars seems like afterthought and won't lend much to gameplay after starting area. Looting corpses for money is very easy. But those problems aren't nothing compared how bad end game is which must be probably one of the worst I've played. It's time-constrained pipe-running in midst of one-shotting grenade-spam enemies spawning from thin air. If you eventually grind it through by memorizing enemy positions, bugged end game makes you finally turn difficulty down and restarting from auto-save. Or go to YouTube for end video.
