reviewText:
GSC Game World had an unexpected hit with S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl and they keep the momentum going by developing a prequel and pushing it out the door in about a year and a half after Shadow's release.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky had some tough shoes to fill. Expectations were very high and whlist it can't match the first for gameplay, it manages to deliver on the atmosphere and adds some new gameplay elements which can be considered either frustrating or brilliant.

You play as Zone guide and veteran S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Scar who, after amazingly surviving a deadly emission, is rescued by an unknown faction known as Clear Sky. Located in the Swamps, you must work with them secretly to find out why the zone is getting worse.

The game is a 50/50 mix of areas seen in Shadow of Chernobyl and brand new areas. The old areas have some pretty big changes to them and areas that were safe in the first game might be a complete nightmare this time around and vice versa.

The game focuses a lot of its first half on the war between the various factions located in the Zone. You are free, once outside the Swamps, to join any faction you want (Freedom, Duty, Stalkers, even the Bandits) and have the privliges that faction offers, all whilst still secretly working for the Clear Sky faction that saved your life.

The game has had some of its more interesting elements removed; your character no longer needs to eat and drink to stay alive, the systems for detecting how visible you are and how much noise you are making have also been removed.

Finding artifacts is now a bit more challenging then before; in Shadow of Chernobyl they would be bobbing up and down in random places around the Zone and you could just run up to them and pick them up maybe whilst avoiding some anomolies. In Clear Sky, artifacts are now invisible but you have a detector that can guide you to them, you just have to work your way through the deadly anomalies, get close to it and it appears for you to collect. This risk/reward mechanism enhances the values of artifacts greatly.

The story sadly isn't as interesting as the first game and instead of most of the spoken dialogue being in Ukranian like in the first game, it has been translated into very rough English that sounds forced and out of place. This can take away from some of the atmosphere of being a foreigner in a completely strange environment.

The game also has a nasty habit of making enemies invincible unless you are close enough. No more picking off people from a distance which can be incredibly frustrating at times.

It isn't as good as Shadow of Chernobyl story-wise and mechanicly but the atmosphere and general improvements make up for it. A worthy addition to the series and worth playing!

P.S. You can grab the CLEAR SKY COMPLETE" modification to fix crash to desktop bugs and translation problems."

reviewText:
Great game. 8/10.

Graphics are amazing, and still beautiful in 2015. I played it a long time ago and it's even better now than I remember. Patched up pretty well, doesn't crash or glitch as much as it used to. In fact, it never crashed when I played it this time round, except a couple of times when fiddling with settings. AI is so much better than in Shadow of Chernobyl, and dialogue is voiced (not your character's voice unfortunately), even has full English dialogue (half of combat shouting is in Russian, and it's better that way).

Super immersive, nice music. There is a bug with music where it randomly cuts off when exploring, dunno what's with that. Pretty unfortunate considering the ambient music when exploring is fantasticly immersive. Also ambient sounds are great. Dynamic music in settings is bleh, it basically turns on combat music to play when in combat, and that isn't really fun.

Storyline is magnificent, and graphics are insane. This game was made in '08 and has god rays, bump maps, the lot. The Map is huge, exploring is extremely rewarding and side quests are fun. Extremely well optimized as well for both nVidia and AMD cards. Great game.

My biggest problem with it is the ending mission and cutscene. The cutscene left too much in the open, it didn't really explain that everyone was being brainwashed or whatever, or that this is how stalkers are made into fanatic monolith worshippers. The ending mission was just a disaster, once you (SPOILERS AHEAD) enter Chernobyl NPP you're supposed to attack Strelok, and honestly it feels like they rushed the game at the end there. Pretty bad mission. Fully scripted and badly made. Like a mission I would've made in Spore Galactic Adventures. Animations were terrible in the end, jesus.

So the final mission was super anti-climatic and actually more hilarious and sad than anything else. Too bad, for such a great game. Kinda like Mass Effect 3, I guess. Lowered my rating from 9 to 8.

Oh yeah, and I recommend playing in master difficulty, so much more fun and realistic that way. Headshots are instakills.

reviewText:
This is an odd game in the series. It has a heavier focus on combat over anomolies. My main complaint was the mess that is the Faction Wars, lopsided sides mean either a battle up or downhill depending on your faction, assuming you can even finish without squads getting stuck or endless assaults. It is a solid game, but it gives way to linear final areas with little warning leaving your character possibly VERY under prepared.

Despite this fans have unofficial mods and patches that greatly enhance the game. Overall I got 35 hours out of it, being the fan of the STALKER series I have to say it is worth playing at least once.

I value it at $20, considering it's normal price is $10 if it goes on a steam sale definitely worth a buy.

reviewText:
I enjoyed this game a lot when it first came out. It's highly customizable and there is a huge community constantly pumping out mods and tweaks for this series.

You play a russian scoundral, your goal is to infiltrate the zone (Chernobyl). Along the way you will meet mutant pig dogs, cows with human faces, bandits, freedom fighters, nazis, scientists. You name it.

The world is basically persistent and you will have to do things to aid your particular faction, like kill bandits or mutants, find vodka, whatever.  The different npc factions are constantly fighting over parts of the zone and you are caught in the middle.

Will you become a stoner and join the freedom faction?

Will you become a cold hearted killer and join the duty faction?

It's up to you, run around and kill stuff and steal radio-active thingys that give you bonus states. If you are a sci-fi fan or a shooter fan you should definitely try this game.

reviewText: Is an auto save really THAT difficult? I hate the copious amount of dying and restarting from a time an hour ago because everytime I complete a mission I assume it saves. Well guess what, this game next to NEVER saves! Maybe they thought the autosave would be too easy or less realistic you say?! Well I say Bull&$#!, because, its WAY less realistic to keep pressing esc it open a menu in the middle of a firefight to save, its rediculous. It strips away what would have been a much better and improved STALKER. This HUGE, GIGANTIC, HUMONGOUS, even TITANIC issue completely detracts from the game and it is and/or was such a simple problem that should have been fixed in the first place. How did you manage to fix all the other flaws and MISS THIS ONE!!!\n\nI supposed I would still reccomend this game, but, with a caution that unless you get into the habit of interrupting the game to save, you'll probably end up throwing your computer across the room after replaying the same mission 5 or 6 times.

reviewText:
I could not get into this game the way I did the original, even though it has been tweaked and improved. The visuals are amazing but the whole clan wars thing never gelled for me. And the sense of purpose that drove me through the first (insanely difficult) STALKER is missing here. There is also no sign of the ultra-cool storyline that popped up just often enough in the first game.

Oh, and the enemy still can head shoot you in pitch dark when you are hiding behind a tree.

Not recommended.

reviewText: Not a fan, the game is clunky and the shooting mechanics would be comical if it wasn't so tragically frustrating. When you shoot a bad guy, he winces a little, then you shoot him again but if you shoot him TOO SOON after your last shot, it doesn't even register. I emptied 2 mags at someone in close quarters to kill them. 2 magazines, because the game is almost turn-based in that it allows the enemy to get up again and shoot you before your next bullet will hit him.\n\nIn addition, the voice acting is terrible. I've never heard a Russian call someone a homie" but today I have. The voices repeat as well
date: with essentially 1 voice actor for most of the game. Not to mention the repeated dialogue every time you re-enter an area or have to repeat a mission or if the same thing happens multiple times.\n\nWorse yet is the mission mechanics. I've beaten the game about 5 times now, and I can definitely recommend this game, besides a few gamebreaking bugs that can be fixed with mods, this game is pretty damn good. The amount of russian yelling during firefights will make anyone turn into a beefy ukrainian bandit, the bloodsuckers are spooky, mutants and humans alike are hard to kill, and there's an abundance of russian weapons. reviewText: The best version of a fantastic open world wasteland franchise. Like the Metro series, STALKER is a post-apoctolypic semi-mysitcal (Russians seem to like having paranormal elements in thier scifi) Russian game. However, while the Metro series is linear (yet finds room for female characters) STALKER is almost totally open (yet almost totally empty of women). Also unlike Metro, STALKER tends to run fairly well on my machine.\nClear Sky is an enhancement of the STALKER formula. Several addtions are present, not the least of which are gun mods (your favorite weapons can be useful forever now, instead of quickly replaced whenever a new gun appears) and a more interesting story. If your like me and Fallout never really did it for you, give this game a shot.

reviewText:
TL:DR version:
Good game. Not as good as the first game Shaodw Of Chernobyl as this one shows all the signs of a rushed game. But with some mods installed it's still very enjoyable.


Long version:
Prequel to the first STALKER game Shadow Of Chernobyl (SOC).

Compared to the first one, which is a masterpiece, this game is short, buggier, and just generally a rushed game.

They only made like 2 new maps while reusing all the textures and maps from SOC yet still manage to code it badly so it's full of bugs. Simply a lackluster effort.

IMPORTANT TIP:
DO NOT USE QUICK-SAVE QUICK-LOAD FUNCTION BUILT INTO THE GAME UNLESS YOU WANT TO HAVE CORRUPTED SAVEFILE THAT FORCE YOU TO START THE GAME OVER.

So, in order to enjoy this, you will need community-made mods"
date:
or patches since they fix bugs the developers are too lazy to fix.

Sky Reclamation Project (SRP) (thank you Decane)
http://www.gsc-game.com/index.php?t=community&s=forums&s_game_type=xr2&thm_page=1&thm_id=23248&sec_id=19

This mod is a must as it fixes many game-crashing issues and it changes no gameplay so you can play the game how it's meant to be played.


Clear Sky Complete (CS COMPLETE) (thank you Pavel)
http://artistpavel.blogspot.ca/2010/01/mod-clear-sky-complete.html

The COMPLETE mods for the STALKER games are nice because they make the game look and sound better and play better. HOWEVER
recommended: even though this mod contains SRP
hoursPlayed: the SRP is an early version and does NOT include many fixes the most current version of SRP has. You WILL encounter game crashes and maybe even CORRUPT savefiles with this so use at your own risk.\n\nNow if you have some modding experience or some general knowledge of how script mods work then you can merge the up-to-date version of SRP with CS COMPLETE.  This is what I did so I can enjoy good graphcis+sound with no crashes."

reviewText:
Unlike SoC I'd say pass on this one.

The enemies are pure bullet sponges. You can put half an AK clip into a guys head and he would still be standing. Standing out in the open shooting you with his sniper shotgun from about a hundred feet away. Difficulty setting will not help. All it does is make enemies more of a bullet sponges. Because of it the gunplay is just unenjoayble. I went to take a group of bandits. There were five of them. I had just over 600 bullets. My AK is always set on single shot so I can at least try to go for precision. By the end of the raid. I had about two dozen bullets left. Minus about 10 medkits because nearly every one of their shots was spot on.

Friendly AI is even worse. Their pathfinding is horrific. You will constantly pushed out of cover, into anomalies, radioactive water. All they do is rush enemy head on to get killed so you will fail a mission.

This pretty much ruined my game. I have tried using mods, but it seems none of the mods actually address those issues. None that I found, anyway.
Skip this one and go straight for Call of Prypiat if you already have Shadow of Chernobyl.

reviewText:
Apart from the bugs and some weaknesses I really liked the first game.

But this one I can't really recommend. This game is even more buggier than the first one - still, years after first release.

A few things were changed for the better - but unfortunately most changes made the game actually worse. For example there isn't really a reliable radiation warning anymore. Sometimes you just die almost instantly - without even having the chance to cure yourself. Even worse: You don't get a warning while your health goes down.
This is just one example for so many things that are just frustrating, especially because they make no sense at all and could have been easly avoided.

At the end the whole game mutates from an open world game to a (badly) scripted one way" shooter with an ending I didn't even see
date: because - you guessed it - it's bugged."

reviewText:
tl;dr Don't buy this because it's the cheapest stalker game. The original may cost twice as much, but with the Oblivion Lost mod, you can get the minimal added content from this game in the original. Clear Sky is simply SoC with a worse campaign, 3 extra maps, and a more annoying faction system. Simply patching the campaign/maps from this game into the original will provide a better game than this one.

Faction Wars ruins the entire game.

Having the military hate you wasn't enough, you'll constantly be met with stalkers who try to extort money from you, demand you defend their settlements which they make no attempt to defend themselves, and perma-agro if you walk the wrong places or refuse to allow them to extort you. Everyone wants you dead, and there's no ♥♥♥♥ing AK ammo anywhere. Pistols often jam twice in a row or on the first round of new magazines.

reviewText: Stalker clear sky… A standalone addon to the Stalker game, which was very interesting from the side of new or fixed gameplay procedures and features, most noticeable from which are clan wars and system of weapon and gear upgrades. Also the feature with emissions where you in the middle of normal exploring all of sudden have to run fast to any shelter or die under not-so-clear-sky of the Zone. And new system of loot hunting, where you need special detector to find the Zone relics… And many other little things, most of them were invented and even implemented by the original game community.\n\nBeing a hard fan, obsessed with the Stalker immerse world, I was able to made it through all Clear Sky quite fast, when it was just released. And I even felt the need to protect that title from blasphemous critics, who’s just not getting the point… But then I started the game for the second time, to really enjoy all its secrets and tight spots. And now I was puzzled with so many development decisions. Why they done it like this? Really, there should be some other way, there is no any logical base for this move. And that turn. And that was unnecessarily too… Now I feel only a shame for the developers, who ruined such interesting setting with totally unreasonable game plot. And, the worst thing is what all the bad stuff comes at player right away, just from the start! The first level in Swamps, after open wastes, forests and industrial compounds of the first game we need to follow the narrow passages... That's even worse than playing the second Crysis game right after the first one! A way worse. And after you manage through Swamps, the gameplot rushes you to go right on the army's outpost, with the outrageous machinegun (if you never played the game, just watch some vid's about Clear sky military machinegun" on the youtube
date: there will be plenty). And if you managed to run out of that setup
recommended: you'll come into the Main Clear Sky Feature - the Clan Wars questline. Things finally starting to get interesting after Cordon... right until the moment you realise that all those clan wars are broken beyond repair. The major tip in the community about that quest line - don't do that!\n\nI can say the same about the whole Clear Sky in general. Unless you're a hardboiled Stalker veteran and going to download (or create) some mods for Clear Sky - don't even bother to start it
hoursPlayed: just get the Call of Pripyat instead
voteText: for much better experience.\n\nMe
helpfulPercent: I prefer the first STALKER game the most
votesHelpful: even without mods. Even vanilla Shadow of Chernobyl gives you the biggest amount of adventure
votesTotal: and diversity of gaming experience. Both Clear Sky and Call of Pripyat are just two (of many) mods with the hope to improve some gameplay aspects. And Clear Sky is a lost hope. It done some good
votesFunny: but as a standalone game - it's a very frustrating experience
commentsCount: not worth of your time. Mark 5/10."

reviewText:
If I were going to be as fair with this review as this game was with me, it would be a one-sided argument of anger and frustration, lined with bits of compliments. However, I'm going to give this game something it never gave me: A ten second head start and a bandage when I really needed it,

So for starters, let's be genuinely honest here; This is the most unique shooter experience I've ever dealt with. For starters, I've never played a game in which you fight armies of angry Russians armed with Iron Curtain weapons and even a few westernized weapons while I only have weapons with effective equivalence of Airsoft guns. Furthermore, every single person in the Zone is a better pitcher than anyone on any baseball team on earth. I mean, I have never been hit in the forehead with a grenade quite so often as I have been in in this game. I could cower behind a wall and say a prayer that I don't die and get hit with a grenade(Not the explosion, it literally bounces off my character) from half the combat platform away. Fast-Travel does exist, but it is quite literally the least convenient source of mobility since holding L2 to walk forward on a Playstation system.

I believe I've made enough statements on how bad it may be there, but there are in fact positives. I am basing this review off my own personal experience, so certain aspects which may be good or bad for me may not be experienced by you personally.

Now the start of the game is interesting enough, so long as you have a well enough understanding of the map and controls and how to utilize your PDA and the Artifact tracker. Seeing as I did not have a great understanding of these things, I went into the swamps and got half way to the second area of the game without completing the first two missions. So be warned, follow the yellow arrow and monitor the grey arrow as well. Now to the good aspects for real

Pros:
+Vast area to explore; The Swamps are interesting to explore but only so long as you can avoid the anomalies.
+Many different weapons and upgrades available
+Random encounters with Mutants make this a horror experience as much as a shooter
+Upgrades have weight to them, just as they have consequences
+Buildings offer a lot of atmosphere

Cons:
-Fast Travel can be the most expensive habit in the game
-Most buildings have the most amazing atmosphere, but are too often empty of much worth exploring
-Invisibility also means transparent/not able to be touched physically by weapons
-T is for Tedium!
-The ending sequence of the game is literally the best reason to Rage Quit
-Game Breaking Bugs(Example: If you retrieve your gear before you go into Duty territory and talk to the commander, the option to talk to anyone is lost and the game can no longer be continued)
-Pistols do not have iron sights but assault rifles do(Contrast to the older game, Shadow of Chernobyl)
-Dude from Freedom Faction MAY TRY to sell you drugs

Overall, it's not a great game. It's not a good game. It's barely within the respective zone for being an Okay game. I gave this game a legitimate try. I gave it serveral tries. As a matter of fact, on the last sequence of the game, I gave about sixty-four tries. However, if I were to count only the amount of times I restarted the campaign, it would be six. Three of those were due to glitches, three were due to Laptop changes and difficulty adjustments.

My Final Rating for this game is
A Red First-Aid Kit/10

It's fine, but doesn't do much for you other than familiarize you with some controls and environments of the game, even if it isn't of a similar layout to the other games. It's good enough to hold you over until you can get the other two far superior versions of the game(Shadow of Chernobyl and Call of Pripyat). While it may quench your thirst for a Nuclear-Disaster based First-Person-Shooter, it is like comparing Resident Evil to the Resident Evil Remake; Only imagine that the Remake came out first.

You can literally skip this installment.

Running in Windows XP SP2 compatibility mode did not change anything. Disabling DX10 enhanced lighting allows the game to run but results in increased flickering. Now is playable.

reviewText:
The game isn't terrible, but it's not great either. The game devs were quite cruel when making this game.

-Possible Spoiler Alert-

Pros:
-Repair system. This was much needed, as equipment tends to degrade quickly, which can make the game unnecessarily difficult.
-Upgrades. Feeling of progression with the ability to improve your weaopns and armor.

Cons:
The game devs were really cruel when making this game.
-The beginning of the game is pretty dumb. The bandits have all of the advantages against you (better accuracy, can spray accurately, tank more bullets than you), and you're constantly in 1v8 situations with little to no cover.
-A powerful sniper rifle (VSS Vintorez) is available at the very beginning of the game. However, it is unusable without paying a hefty repair cost, and the ammunition it uses cannot be obtained until late in the game, at which this sniper is readily available. In short, it's just dead weight.
-There's a machine gun emplacement that guns you down while you run for your life. This is impossible on the hardest difficulty, and even on the easiest difficulty, the machine gun will probably warrant a somewhat expensive repair.
-At one point in the game, bandits steal all of your money. Adds insult to injury.
-Bandits are total ♥♥♥♥♥, but only they can help you install the best armor upgrades.
-Not many side quests.
-The is too linear. I found myself passing through each area exactly once with little reason to backtrack. Unlike the other STALKER games, there's no central hub(s) where one can settle down and relax.

Overall, not recommended unless you're a hardcore STALKER fan that wants bragging rights for playing all the games.

reviewText:
Maybe the game just isn't for me but here are some of the reasons why I dislike it.

Weapons and ammo are named for people who like guns in real life rather than being named so that gamers can easily identify what is what at a seconds glance.

The bleeding mechanic is annoying. You get bleeding for pretty much any hit so you better scavenge any and all healing items (apart from food which is just going to weigh you down) you come across.

Your weapons rarely feel like they have an impact" on enemies. You can hit an enemy 8 times with a weapon and they barely look like they are harmed by it. There is no limping
recommended: no trying to escape when their life is too low
hoursPlayed:
no stumble when hit by a heavy impact weapon like a shotgun. The only times it feels like your weapons have an impact is when you hit an enemy in the head at which point they're instakilled.

Combat in general is tedious. You have to attack multiple enemies and they all take so many bullets (unless you manage to get good headshots (which isn't easy with how inaccurate weapons are)) to go down while you only need to take a handful to die. You end up playing pop a mole from cover most of the time and there is rarely any other tactic to use since if you kill an enemy pretty much all other enemies are alerted to your presence so sneaking is out of the question. And maybe it is just because I never found a good long range weapon but sniping wasn't viable for me. Neither was storming the place either. It's pretty much just pop a mole from cover for the most part.

The dialogue in the game is "topic dialogue". Meaning that your character asks questions and the NPC's spew out paragraphs of exposition. I don't care for this kind of dialogue as characters just end up being meat shield/walking lore pamphlets.

I'm not well versed with this regions names
voteText: culture and dialects so for me every character blended together with one another. Pretty much no one stood out so I ended up not caring about any of them.\n\nOn that note

reviewText: I loved the first STALKER game Shadow of Chernobyl, and I enjoyed Call of Pripyat, but this is a pain in the ♥♥♥.  The problem is primarily level design.  In the other two games you can handle big challenges your way.  Here, the last third of the game is a very lineral duneon crawl.  In some games that works, but when you have such a wide open first part of the game, the restrictions on the last third are painful.   Maybe there is a mod that helps?\n\nIf you love the other two games then, fine, get this one, but prepare for frustrsation.  I should have left this one alone.

reviewText:
Do not purchase this game.

It's not quite anything like the other two STALKER games. It's very linear and not as fun and or even immersive as the other two games. Not to mention that it is missing tons of features and has some major performance problems.

If you're a die hard fan, go for it, but don't expect an amazing experience.

reviewText:
While the first STALKER is old, it has it's charm. This must be renamed STALKER Clear ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t or Linear Scripting Hell. They re- use some areas of the old one, but that has it's charm. They've changed a lot and nothing for the better.

For instance, bandages are highly needed now cause a medkit wont stop the bleeding...no bandage and you will die slowly. And then there is the case when you bandage yourself and you are still losing health, with no other clear indication why! Bandaging again or a medkit does not work. But wait there is more, enemies can see you from miles away, while you still struggling from where that head shot came from. After a while you find out that mr. freaking bandit almost killed you with a pistol from 200 yards away, while yours is inaffective anywhere but point-blank.
While in the old stalker you could use an object to hide from incoming fire, in here hiding does not make sense, when they spot you, they will fire upon you and will hit you. And they will spot you, even crouching and walking pace(slowest movement almost no sound) they will spot you in daylight or in the night as if they all wear NV goggles. Yes they will spot you and shoot around freaking corners or through objects...but that's oke FF. Well hell no it's not, cause once you come out of the swamps, the militairy is waiting for you. They'll ask you to go back, one more step and you are fodder. But you need to go that way cause you can't go another way. You cannot sneak upon or away from them. You need to go to the trader on your left and the only way to do it, is by running, they will sent a squad of 3 with body armor and very accurate akms...and one thing an akm is not... Good, you've survived by running...but those 3 militairy dudes followed you and are killing the stalkers in the village(3 of them) and you are next.
One last thing, I was irritated in the old stalker by a guy in pripyat, come here stalker, my information...yeah that guy. Now they turned every freaking talking ape in the zone like him. Stand too close and they will spam you the same question over and over again....

Save your money, use it to make a trip to the real chernobyl instead...I bet ya ,kissing the sacrofaag there is more fun then this game.

reviewText:
I won't say this is a bad sequel, but this game has been very frustrating to finish.

Compared to the first, there are some new useful features like fast travel (but very, very limited) and weapon/armor repairing and modifying.
There is also a faction war system, that is cool and seems like the main feature of this new chapter, but it is (and should be, to avoid problems in game) totally avoidable.

The plot is very trivial, unbalance is very annoying in some parts and bugs can oblige you to start again from a very old save state.

The unbalancing, in particular, happened just approaching the last part of the main story. I had a very poor equipment and I was waiting to meet a shop to get better, but for like 3 areas, along the way, I met not a single shopper, only guys that could only repair my equipment (not even enhance it).
So at some point I found myself in a long way without turning back until the end of the game (with no previous warning) with these crappy weapons and armor, and the game turned in a constant loading and dying".

In the end
date: the game feel a lot like its predecessor (intending it in a bad way
recommended: overall it feels just like playing again the first)
hoursPlayed: but with some additional highs and lows that
voteText: depending on the individual game experience

votesHelpful: for me it has been a very bad and frustrating experience."

reviewText: A so-so prequel to Shadow of Chernobyl that re-uses most of the SoC assets to flesh out the original story. Plays a lot better when you ignore the main 'quest' and go wandering. The new faction wars feature would have been the saving grace of the title if it wasn't quite so buggy and had a touch more depth to it.\n\nIt's nice to wrap yourself in the Stalker atmosphere again but overall the game feels too much like a simple (and flawed) expansion rather than a stand-alone game.

reviewText: Worst in the series. Only noteworthy part is the faction wars mechanic, where you can aid the various in game factions in battles against each other for territory. This is pretty cool because you can really change how the game is played with who is friendly/hostile to you and who inhabits what areas. reviewText: One of the most broken games available. Even if you've got a load of extra cash lying around, I wouldn't recommend buying this game. The game seems great at first with wide-open areas and decent visuals but it all goes downhill from there. It seems the vast majority of the game is plagued with radiation that keeps you from exploring it, and all other areas are loaded with bandits and military goons. The biggest problem with the game are the loads of human enemies that litter the world turning it into a standard spray and pray shoot-out, but with a special catch: every single enemy is a bullet sponge that can absorb clip after clip, the only saving grace being that sometimes a headshot will kill them instantly. Other problems rise from certain parts of the game being a pain to get to because of broken hit-boxes or dozens of 'anomalies' being in the way that make traversing slow and mind-numbing. The tutorials also don't explain a whole lot, the UI is mediocre, and secondary quests are a pain to deal with because of a bad map and the many environmental blockages that will get in your way. It would be enjoyable to wander the expansive wastes, but sadly every five steps you take runs you into an irradiated field or an anomaly that will explode into a cloud of lightning and send you flying. Overall, a terrible game with basically no redeeming qualities.

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky starts off with a terrible first impression. The main menu not only looks almost exactly like the first game's, but even the main menu music is the same. This isn't necessarily bad, but it's like a sick foreshadowing to the travesty that is this game.

GRAPHICS
Visually, this game is fairly good. However, it's nothing impressive. The first game allowed great immersion, even if you were only playing at the medium graphical settings. This game, however, fails to draw you into the setting, and I just groaned in contempt when I reached the end, where even the legendary and infamous Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant failed to stimulate my visual senses.

GAMEPLAY
The game in terms of gameplay is definitely superior to the first entry. With more accurate weaponry and less shooting-through-walls glitches, I found myself not getting nearly as infuriated with the game as I did with the first. However, the survival/horror was absent entirely. The mutants were nearly nonexistent, whereas in the first game I was constantly on edge with the terror of the fantastic and varied enemies. But in this game, I found myself bored with fighting too many human enemies. Still, the mechanics are far superior than the first game, and I can give this props for that.

MULTIPLAYER
Don't play this mode. Please, for the love of all that is good and sane in this world, NEVER PLAY THIS MODE. Weapon balance is nearly nonexistent, maps and game modes are recycled from the first game. On top of that, you'll be hard pressed to find anyone playing this game's multiplayer. Stay clear of it.

STORY
The game's story takes a massive hit. It is nothing more than a pale shadow in comparison to Shadow of Chernobyl. This game takes place one year before the events of the first game and tells the story of the zone and how Strelok came to be where he was in the first game. Sounds great on paper, but is overall disappointing. The game says multiple times that there are new areas to explore in the game because emissions have changed the radiation levels around the zone. This is complete and utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T. There are a total of two new places to explore in the game. Otherwise, you visit literally EVERY SINGLE LOCATION FROM THE FIRST GAME. Actually, even less than that! The fact that I completed this game's story, while completing a few of the dull, uninspiring optional missions along the way, in a whopping 6 hours, proves that the developers were simply lazy with the game. You will shoot hundreds of humans all around the same places you've been to in the first game, and then sometimes shoot a mutant, repeat. Strelok is barely in the game at all, very little of the first game's supposed background history is given in this game, and it fails to inspire and enthrall like the first game. There was no mystery, horror, or intrigue throughout the course of this painfully short campaign, and it felt like a chore to go through.

VERDICT
This game is $10 U.S. dollars not worth spending. This was a money-grabber after the success that was S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl. There was so much potential in this game that was simply wasted, and I was painfully reminded throughout the course of the game that I wasted money on a game that I will probably never play again. Make no mistake, this is one of the worst video games that I have ever played, a copy-and-paste of the original with less content and a worthless story.

RATING: 5/10

reviewText:
Prequel to Shadows of Chernobyl and mostly same mechanics if not all with more things for better & worst.

The artifacts' stats are now simplified and all except a very select few give off radiation. Those select few remove radiation so most of these ones are rare to find. Artifacts and anomalies can also now be detected via detectors so long as you're close enough to said artifacts and as you progress you can buy more improved detectors.

The guns are all pretty much like the ones in SoC, you'll be lucky to get a headshot with a beginning gun. Clear Sky added a new upgrade and repair system that specific NPCs can provide for you. Repair is simply just to restore the condition of your weapons and armor whereas upgrades can vastly improve the actual weapons and armor you're using from guns decreasing in weight, armor having more specific protection stats, etc. However specific NPCs won't know how to upgrade certain guns or certain parts unless you go to another NPC or acquire a flash drive of the data for better improving equipment that that specific NPC can work with.

Fast travel is now a thing where you can pay guides to take you to specific places of every explorable map. Prices vary on how far you're going.

Clear Sky's got a new faction war system where a group from a specific faction can start to go to another faction's territory and try to take its place and if somehow you're friends with both sides you can help whichever side or let them go at it until one side loses so as you don't take a side. Unfortunately important characters can die from this so getting specific tasks may become impossible.

One of the most irritating things about this game are the random emissions that can immediately kill you if you don't go inside an indicated shelter within the time limit. If you're the type who likes to loot and sell a lot of junk these can be a pain in the fanny for if you're too far from a shelter and you have a wide load you may have to sacrifice said loot just so you can get to the shelter in time. The emissions also take forever to actually happen (like, 1 or 2 minutes I didn't really check when it starts) so even if you're conveniently next to shelter you'll have to just sit inside and wait for the emission to end before going back to your usual S.T.A.L.K.E.R. ways.

The spook factor, I thought, was gone and especially so since you don't really explore any labs. Going through the Red Forest though was cool at night but it wasn't really anything special, especially when dealing with annoying Bloodsuckers.

It plays like Shadows of Chernobyl but much of what made the first game cool seemed to be gone and as a fan of the first game this was pretty disappointing. Even the two endings here weren't really interesting and you can probably skip this and just move on to Call of Pripyat.
voteText: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful

reviewText: On paper it sounded like a great game, a survival/horror shooter with some RPG elements, but it is hopelessly poorly implemented.  It is so buggy and unbalanced it is nigh on unplayable without modding (I tried Complete, Sky Reclamation Project, and Arsenal Overhaul), and even then it is not really great.  If you are a mind-reader you might do better, as it also has next to no tutorial, leaving it to the player to divine how things work, and what you need to do to complete mission objectives is not always made clear, so you are left to blunder around and try to figure it out, all the while under a rain of death from the infallible bullet-sponge AI.  Prepare to die over and over while you do that, which is weird for a survival game, the point of which is surely to NOT die.  I gave up on this one, I was just not having fun.

If you're the type who likes to loot and sell a lot of junk these can be a pain in the fanny for if you're too far from a shelter and you have a wide load you may have to sacrifice said loot just so you can get to the shelter in time. The emissions also take forever to actually happen (like, 1 or 2 minutes I didn't really check when it starts) so even if you're conveniently next to shelter you'll have to just sit inside and wait for the emission to end before going back to your usual S.T.A.L.K.E.R. ways.

The spook factor, I thought, was gone and especially so since you don't really explore any labs. Going through the Red Forest though was cool at night but it wasn't really anything special, especially when dealing with annoying Bloodsuckers.

It plays like Shadows of Chernobyl but much of what made the first game cool seemed to be gone and as a fan of the first game this was pretty disappointing. Even the two endings here weren't really interesting and you can probably skip this and just move on to Call of Pripyat.

reviewText: On paper it sounded like a great game, a survival/horror shooter with some RPG elements, but it is hopelessly poorly implemented.  It is so buggy and unbalanced it is nigh on unplayable without modding (I tried Complete, Sky Reclamation Project, and Arsenal Overhaul), and even then it is not really great.  If you are a mind-reader you might do better, as it also has next to no tutorial, leaving it to the player to divine how things work, and what you need to do to complete mission objectives is not always made clear, so you are left to blunder around and try to figure it out, all the while under a rain of death from the infallible bullet-sponge AI.  Prepare to die over and over while you do that, which is weird for a survival game, the point of which is surely to NOT die.  I gave up on this one, I was just not having fun.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game as I had played the first STALKER game, however I found it has too many faults (and the first had it's fair share).

1. Re-spawn bugs: NPCs that you just shot dead, and an area is clear, they look like they leap back from the dead or magically appear in front of you - making it impossible to take a base as your team NPCs never arrive, they seem to go wandering off in the wilderness.
2. Persistence bugs and fails: leave an area and immediately return, and all the ground you gained has disappeared with your NPC bases taken back instantly (clock showing only minutes difference).
3. Later in the game with improved weapons and armour, it seems that the low level weapons some NPCs have become more powerful than your own - such that a shotgun can take you out at 100+ metres. Whilst the fully upgraded sniper rifle won't even take an NPC out with a headshot, often requiring a full clip of 10+ shots to kill a NPC.
4. None existent game levelling, comparing all game play levels and there was little to no difference between Novice to Veteran.
5. Missions that appear and disappear within seconds, not even allowing you time to run to them even when only a few metres away.

I have played many FPS, 3PS and RPG games for over a decade, always at highest difficulty. I am a fan of the series of Fallout, Crysis, CoD, Battlefield, Far Cry, Skyrim, Dragonage, Mass Effect etc etc. But this one unfortunately is not going in that list, like I said I really did want to like it, but the above eventually wore me down, I don't want to finish it... so I really can't recommend it - follwing this review it's being uninstalled.

reviewText:
I usually don't do reviews, but this game made me want to give it a shot.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.:Clear Sky is, in my opinion, the worst of the trilogy.

Here's a few reasons why:
-Movement feels sluggish, as if your character is running under water. It makes the exploration extremely unpleasant.
-Bleed is broken. Fall 2 metres -> break legs -> use all bandages -> die from bleed
-Aiming is impossible. Not only does crouching not help, but looking down sights does f**k all.
-If you manage to hit somebody, you'd think a bullet to the knee would slow them down. Not here...
-Story is stock material, characters and places not as interesting as in the other games.

All in all, if you want a good post-apocalyptic shooter rpg, play the other installments of the series (preferably modded), or any of the Fallout series.

10/10 best swamp walking simulator 2015.

reviewText:
I loved Shadow of Chernobyl. It wasn't exactly as originally promised (the developers removed a handful of features), still, the game had a unique atmosphere that made it memorable. Then, not long after Clear Sky was released and everything I liked about SoC simply vanished.

Clear Sky was an unnecessary sequel. The developer quickly made a sequel to cash in on a successful and famous game. They advertised it as a prequel story as the protagonist here follows the hero from the first game. But shouldn't you introduce new environments or areas in a sequel even if it is intended as a prequel story? You venture through the very same areas - even the map looks the same. At the beginning, you have a swamp-like are which is new, yes, but then you encounter the same places.

The game uses the same engine but with DX10 features included. Still, you have a handful of bugs and the game can be very difficult at times - not only do you encounter respawning enemies but sometimes it is difficult to understand why it takes so many shots to finally eliminate someone.

What happened to the super ending of the original game? Here, the final encounter in the centre of the zone seems rushed and non-creative. What happened to the different endings we had in SoC based on the gameplay-style we followed? Where are the new enemy types / gameplay elements / objects / weapons we expect from a sequel? Make no mistake: introducing new things is not a must but at least I would have expected to have the game rid of all the bugs it had in the original one.

I remember the forest area being different. Instead of following the route next to it we finally ventured into it. It was dark and creepy and provided the necessary atmosphere. But this was the only thing in Clear Sky that I remember as good.

You can pick this one up if you are a Stalker fan but I recommend downloading and installing the Complete Mod which rids the game of above-mentioned issues and introduces several new features.

reviewText:
I'm a big STALKER fan and one of my friends, who is a much larger fan of everything related to the series, told me to stay away from Clear Sky. I figured that even something vaguely Stalkery would be still pretty good because Pripyrat and the original were very enjoyable, but I after playing through Clear Sky I see why people say stay away.

1. Very short
2. Very linear with exploration discouraged
3. Less focus on monsters/mutants and more on killing hundreds of human enemies
4. Ending is terrible
5. You have very few, if any, choices beyond which faction to fight for
6. Faction Wars idea feels like it is barely fleshed out
7. Upgrade system and a few other things tied to the factions are not fun
8. Little sense of what either of the other two Stalkers are all about (weird ♥♥♥♥, exploration, mutants and being a Stalker)
9. Only one ending as far as I can tell
10. Several repetitive sections were you just kill waves after waves of human enemies

Let me explain some of those a little more. The game is a bit short, especially comapred to the other two. My record says 20 hours, but 3-4 hours of that are idle-time when I left it on and the rest was doing absolutely everything I could in terms of side missons/faction wars and trying to explore areas that didn't want to explored. I imagine you could easily run though it (without trying hard) in less than 10 hours.

The entire feeling of world is almost erased from what was created in the original game (and Pripyrat even though that came after this one). You can only find things if they are randomly located by this guy back at the original base that randomly gives you locations of stashes, or if you buy tips from people for stashes. If you happen to find that stash on your own without doing either of those things then nothing will be in it, hence discouraging exploration. A lot of the areas are also pretty closed off or empty besides human enemies, which kind of give tiers of loot depending on where you are in the games story. All of this might be fine if the story was good, it isn't because it goes against the original's story and just kind of sucks all around, or if the Faction War system was actually good.

The Faction War system, which is a big focus of the game and one of the main things going on all the time (also one of the main reasons there is less focus on mutants and exploration) is a really shallow offering. You have no real impact on anything and only if you get a mission to take an area will the A.I. faction you are fighting for actually go and capture it. They give you a lot of good rewards for doing missions and taking over areas, but it is all very temporary and the whole system isn't the slightest bit dynamic. The A.I. rarely does anything on their own, they have no ambition, and even when you do the big mission" that is supposed to supress an enemy faction the area is only captured for 15 minutes at most. You cannot command any squads
date: request reinforcements if you take somewhere on your own
recommended: or really interact with your faction at all beyond their main bases
hoursPlayed: which just offer shops. It was very disappointing to experience because it could have been something much more complex
voteText: dynamic and enjoyable.\n\nSomewhere in all of this is an actual STALKER game with great environments
helpfulPercent: horrifying enemies
votesHelpful: a great upgrade system and so much more
votesTotal: but I whole heartedly recommend playing Pripyrat instead even if you have already beaten it before and you are just looking for another go at this wonderful world."

reviewText:
Clear Sky - it's the original Stalker all over again - but they kinda took the whole Chernobyl-deal out of it. You get to visit almost all the lame places from the original (even in pretty much the same order), however the majority of them are devoid of the great decayed factory setpieces.

For the most part this feels like a poorly implemented try at doing things a bit more like Battlefield or Call of Duty, if it wasn't for the occasional mutant or radioactive anomaly you wouldn't actually believe it was set in the Stalker universe.

It does  have a lot of gameplay tweaks though (fast travel!) and the gunplay  seems to work much better than in the previous game. Faction wars (despite being bugged) seemed like an interesting mechanic, and the Red Forest now looks much more like the real thing.

Still an underwhelming and mostly forgettable experience.

I tried to play this game when it was released, and i couldn't finish half way through because saving was broken somewhere on the Cordon level.

Now however, when i played the patched version, i played it with Complete Mod, and i still couldn't finish it because i couldn't load any save in Limansk level (the level prior to the game finale) but the autosave at the beginning of the level.

Faction Wars was an interesting idea, but it felt lacking. This game feels like a rushed, unfinished game. I would recommend it, but if i knew that i couldn't finish the game because of the save/load problem, i wouldn't even try it, even though i am one of the greatest Stalkers out there.

reviewText:
Originally posted on June 3, 2009

I loved STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl. It wasn't perfect, but it was a really exciting game. However, after playing STALKER: Clear Sky for over 25 hours, I am unable to continue. The game is broken. Allow me to explain.

Graphically speaking, Clear Sky is a huge step up from SOC. It uses some of the most advanced shadows I've seen in a game, and the day and night cycle is incredibly immersive. All of the haunting art design and character modeling for the first game is there, but with improved models. However, the game is also so poorly optimized that it cannot run DirectX11 shadows without becoming a slide show, and continues to give me burst of awful (5-10 fps) lag on my rig. And trust me, my rig is not the problem. I've confirmed that this problem is widespread among many gamers, and is not just isolated to me.

The sound in the game is exceptional, of course. Weather, ambient noise, howls, fire crackling, gunshots, etc, all really help to immerse you in the zone. I have no complaint's about the sound design.

If the lag was the only issue, I would probably have finished this game lag and all. I certainly tried to. Of course I saw where it was headed, but the thrill *spoiler* of putting Strelok in the place we find him in SOC drove me onward. *spoiler* However, the combat mechanics, which were really great in the first game, especially the gunplay, are broken in this game.

Yes, the AI is more intelligent than in SOC; it uses cover, flanks you, and throws grenades. However, enemies tend to throw grenades in bursts at your EXACT position, and STALKER is NOT a movement friendly game. It feels incredibly unbalanced as one grenade will hurt you even if you sprint away from it immediately, and you will lose your cover. Multiple grenades almost always mean death.

The ballistics model in this game is a big disappointment in comparison to the first. All types of guns are WILDLY inaccurate at ranges above 50 feet, unless they are absolutely tricked out with accuracy upgrades. With a standard AK 74 or Abakan, you can't hit a damn thing at 100m, and are almost always forced to use assault rifles as if they were SMGs (grenade spamming and charging in headlong). I had to spend a good 15000 rubles on my TRS 301 just to get it to perform like it did un-modded in the original game. The AI, of course has none of these accuracy issues, and can happily hit you at 100m plus with any gun in the game, including the MAKAROV!

While the faction wars system is interesting, it's makes the zone feel too crowded, and not nearly as spooky or desolate as in the first game. In addition, whenever you conquer new territory, it takes the AI forever to send backup, which usually consists of 1-3 men to help you fend off the multiple counterattacks the enemy sends, usually consisting of 10 plus total men. You may have total numerical superiority, but if 300 of your best equipped stalkers are sitting in your base territory, you have a problem. This is supposed to be a war, not a one man take down border skirmish.

In conclusion, I'm not wild about the new weapon upgrade system, but I could see it working in a future title, and i love being able to repair my gear, finally. The new detector and revamped anomaly system is good, and the new graphics and AI are great for the most part. Now fix the balance, lag, gameplay issues, performance, and bring back the spookiness, and cut out the generic side quests, and we'll have a great game.

Here's to Call of Pripyat..... *sigh*

reviewText: Meh. Buggy, bland world, uninteresting npc's and quests, half the guns  jam every other clip and like to shoot around people but never at them, you're sprinting back across the map most of the time to turn in a quest you finished an hour ago for a sub-par reward, and it has a *ridiculous* difficulty setting that eventually ruins the game outright (ridiculous because there is a function in the game programming that makes your bullets have a 40%-70% chance to literally disappear out of the air depending on what difficulty you chose). Later in the game, this will make it appear as tho one enemy is eating 2 entire clips right in their face before going down. Game's definitely fun if you like looking at a loading screens - the quicksave and quickload keys are the only useful things in your arsenal the whole time. Overall, just feels like a lot of areas in the game didn't get the attention or time they sorely needed. Don't spend your money on this without doing some in-depth review hunting first. In my opinion, there are plenty of other much better options for the $10 - $20 price range: any Fallout, Far Cry, Borderlands, Deus Ex games - heck, I could go on, and that's just others I've played recently. Play those games if you want a better rpg-shooter hybrid, not STALKER Clear Sky.

reviewText: S.T.A.L.K.E.R Clear Sky is the follow up to the sleeper hit Shadow of Chernobyl, a game that somehow managed to overcome it's many flaws and limitations and be a great game. Clear Sky brings along many new additions and upgrades, particularly in the graphics department. And while all of this sounds great on paper the only thing it manges to accomplish is driving home the point that there are no good or bad ideas, only good and bad executions.\n\nThe core gameplay remains the same, you are a Stalker"
date: a traveler in the cordoned off wasteland that surrounds Chernobyl. An area filled with radiation
recommended: mutated monsters and dangerous anomalies. Not to mention the rather high population of other stalkers and residents of "The Zone" that are also collecting the rare artifacts spawned by the anomalies and the various factions that each try to impose their own ideals on the zone and it's inhabitants.\n\nThe faction system is one of the major new features of Clear Sky. They will send off groups of stalkers on their own attempting to secure various points of importance throughout the game world and if you are allied with them you will often be asked to participate in various offensive and defensive actions as mini-missions. This makes the world seem much more alive and as there are not only constant movement around the maps but it's also directed movement
hoursPlayed:
everybody trying to gain the upper hand.

The second big addition is the increased character customization. Your weapons and armor have many options that allow you to increase their potential in various ways. Many of the upgrades are exclusive as well so instead of making a super gun you have to specialize your weapons and armor. The developers have listened to the community as well and another part of this is the increased rarity of artifacts and the increased difficulty in collection them which is a very welcome addition.

The unfortunate truth however is that both these additions come in a heavily flawed state and especially the faction system will lead to many hours of frustration. The game still has that "raw" feeling
voteText: despite the improved graphics
helpfulPercent: and where in Shadow of Chernobyl this was mostly forgivable the increased problems with Clear Sky makes it come out at you much more.\n\nClear Sky is a unfortunate sequel that hasn't quite grown enough since Shadow of Chernobyl. It still has all of the problems that Shadow of Chernobyl and adds several of it's own which leads to a sequel that is less than it's predecessor."

reviewText:
I was enjoying Clear Sky right up untill my first bug.

BE WARNED!, the game has quite a few serious bugs.

I managed to make it through 20+ hours (I like to explore) before my game started crashing.
While this wouldn't normally be a problem, as you would just reload a previouse save, the game is actually bugged after certain events, and every time you enter the area and get close to base, the game crashes. My understanding is that it is due to loading in the merchants or base boss. Either way the only fix is to use mods or simply play through it.

The game is still playable, so long as you go around the areas, and give up any loot you had stored there. This bug was  serious enough to effect my experience of the game as a whole, as after a while the game started to corrupt more locations (like the main stalker base). After this point I just gave up on the game.

After playing it for 50+ hours even through the bugs, I would rather go and play Call of Pripyat".

My advice is to play Call of Pripyat before this game

reviewText:
A lot of people have rightly said that Clear Sky was disappointing after Shadow of Chernobyl. I agree, mostly because a lot of the maps are just reworkings from the first game. Also, there is a little less depth in the story, tipping the scale into Clear Sky being more of a straight shooter.

However, the 'factions' war element brings something genuinely new to the game. Moreover, all the great visuals are still there and, when the new maps come along from time to time, they are still a real treat! I like the changes that have been made to the artifacts 'system' as well - there are fewer of them to be had, and they are harder (and more dangerous) to acquire. This adds value to their value.

If you have an itch to replay Chernobyl, but perhaps don't want to play through the exact same game again, get Clear Sky, especially if its on offer. Clear Sky proivdes enough of a difference for you to get your STALKER fix!

People tell me that Pripyat is even better again... I'm saving it though!

reviewText:
Firstly S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Clear Sky is almost and exact clone of S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl with some small areas introduced and others removed. I see no problem with this as the story is different and compelling and the introduction of a weapon customization menu was a big step towards S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat where the game was perfected. However this eddition of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series has many less mods avaliable for it and there are many unbalanced aspects to the gameplay which are removed. If you have the money for all three S.T.A.L.K.E.R games get this!
As a veteran of the zone playing far upwards of my logged online hours i would recommend the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series in the following order:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat
S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl
S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Clear Sky
If you love a strong story i'd suggest S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl, but if, like me, you prefer maximized gameplay and a balanced combat system allowing you to aquire your favorite gun right away, then upgrade it to a monster as your progress i'd suggest S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat.

reviewText:
-Core Review-

Gameplay . 8
Music . 6
Graphics . 8
Mechanics . 7.5
Story(s) . 8

Total . 7.5


-Nice Words-

Fun solo adventure, immersive environment, well built characters. That's what you'll find in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. (Clear Sky). This game might or might not give you the spooks, and will definitely have you running around for hours trying to figure some things out. Over all its a beautiful game and I recommend it to most everyone.


-Personal Experience / Old Review-

To give you a idea of how confusing this game is, the first time I played it I thought it was in Russian. Waking up in the middle of a house in a small town where people pull guitars out of there asses after being blown up in a giant nuclear explosion totally makes sense, as does the rest of this game.

This post-nuclear-war game has you wondering who turned off the lights whenever it is night time. Usually in most FPS games ammo is always around the corner but I find myself walking to the next town just to get 60 of my trusty bullets, and I'll definitely have enough time to carve all of my mutated targets names on them by the time I get back to where i originally started.

This game has a great sense of atmosphere and has a story, that starts out unusually so I suggest playing the first one. However it is one of the best single player games I've touched, and by that I mean the series.

Also turrets are OP

reviewText:
Consider this a recommendation for the entire STALKER series so far (latest as of this being Call of Pripyat). The STALKER games are FPS/Survival Horror/RPG hybrids where the emphasis is on the FPS gunplay and the survival elements.

You can get thirsty or hungry or need sleep and have to manage those needs alongside that of the deteriorating conditions of your weapons and armors. Ammunition, food, and drink needed to survive are scarce, but can be traded for with almost anyone if you have the right amount of goods or money to sacrifice for it. The game has large maps you can travel between like a sandbox game, and the gunplay is some of the tightest I've seen with really good gun physics. The games also have a wildlife simulation system similar to the one in place in FarCry 3 in a way; animals and mutants will run around and do their own thing after they spawn and kill each other (and maybe you) for survival or food.

Despite the large amount of freedom these games afford you to carve your own path, they feel very focused and are best approached with a strategic mindset.

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky is the prequel to S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl. I recently delved into this game again, and I figure I should review it. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. has always had a focus on factions, but Clear Sky soups up the faction system like crazy. You can join any of the not-immediately-hostile major factions (i.e. Military and Monolith), which include, off the top of my head, Duty, Freedom, Bandits, Loners, and Clear Sky. You get special gear for joining specific factions. I prefer Duty, personally.
The gameplay is solid, although it's essentially the same as Shadow of Chernobyl but touched up a little bit. The accuracy is dictated by whether or not you are crouching, or if you are using iron sights. You bleed if you are shoot in a non-vital spot, so do enemies. Enemies, if hit in a location that bleeds a lot, will eventually keel over and die or curl up on the ground dying. If you hit an enemy in the head, it's an instant kill, unless they are armored up with some of the more powerful gear, or unless they are a zombie. I think it takes 2 or 3 shots to the head to drop a zombie or a guy wearing an exoskeleton.
A big perk of this game that they added in Clear Sky is the upgrade system. You can attach/detach silencers and scopes, as you could in SoC, but now you can go to NPCs who can upgrade your weapons and armor. You can upgrade gear with composite plates, extra carry weight, artifact slots, etc., and improve accuracy, fire rate, recoil, and even reduce bullet drop and change ammunition type on some weapons.
For those who played SoC, artifacts are significantly harder to find in this game. Rather than being able to see artifacts, you need to find them with an anomalous activity tracker, which will track them with beeps. I strongly suggest getting to Yantar ASAP and upgrading that puppy to one that has a map attached to it.
I feel like there is more to do in this game than SoC, with the faction wars and such. But it does seem like there are less side-missions. That's kind of a con I suppose. Anyway:

This game has a lot of pros: The combat is interestingly difficult and forces you to think out your combat encounters, or have your entire carry weight taken up by medkits (Don't do that, that's a terrible idea). The faction system and faction wars are awesome. The upgrades are neat, the game is gorgeous, and blah blah blah.

On cons: This game suffers from pretty much the same issues that Shadow of Chernobyl did. Those are bugs, lots of bugs, the game tends to crash every so often (Quicksave! F5 is your friend. Do it often!), and... An issue I had with SoC that I still have with this game, is that it has an ABSURD difficulty spike in the last act of the game. I can't help but find it irritating. You have a set-up and souped up gear that has allowed you to breeze through everthing else, and then come the last act, you feel like you're wearing the leather hoodie you start off with, equipped with a... I don't know... BB gun.

Anyway, this game is an excellent game, it should be played.

reviewText: An amazing game with tons of atmosphere and fun, when it works....  even now, years later, this game is still pretty buggy, and they even patched it yesterday (april 24, 2015).  often you will capture an objective and it will take a considerable amount of time before your backup shows up to progress the faction wars.  but when it does work, this game is absolutely amazing, and there are few games like it (although many have tried to mimic its strong points).  Stalker Call of Pripyat is very stable, and arguably a better game, but the maps are smaller, and there is less to do (still a lot though).  I love this game, I have logged over 100 hours in it, but if you are thinking about buying it and havent played call of pripyat, get that instead.

reviewText: Clear Sky is considered the red headed step child of the STALKER franchise, but in all honesty it's my favorite of the 3 STALKER games and I will explain why to you.\nClear Sky (CS) revamped a lot of the clunky design that was present in Shadow of Chernobyl (SoC), and paved the way for a lot of the useful features that were present in Call of Pripyat (CoP).  First off, CS overhauled your PDA immensely, cutting out a lot of the unnecessary features and streamlining your available options.\nArtifacts also received a major makeover in the game in how you acquire them, and their overall functionality.  Thanks to CS, artifact hunting means you have to actually hunt".  In STALKER's predecessor
date: artifacts could be found just laying on the ground and were in a huge abundance.  In CS
recommended: you actually have to jump into anomalies with a special detector to find the goodies inside.  And the goodies are actually worth it as well.  An artifact that increases your endurance (recovery speed from jumping
hoursPlayed: running etc.) has a more limited value than in SoC
voteText: prompting you to equip more than one if you're going out on a long raid.  On the up side
helpfulPercent: health restoring artifacts have a major impact on keeping you alive and actually heal you faster than they do in CoP.  If I had to take a guess
votesHelpful: I'd say that little feature has a lot to do with your character's "gift"
votesTotal: but you'll figure out what that means when you play it.\nThe world feels more alive
votesFunny: with many of the NPCs getting unique voice actors
commentsCount: as well as a lot of them also interacting with each other.  You can really get a feel for this when you get to Freedom's base and meet the two stalkers that keep hijacking the outpost's loudspeaker to talk smack to each other.  Plus the NPCs are more reactive
column16: they will tell you to buzz off if you're trying to talk to them with a gun in their face
column17: or they'll smack your gun out of your hands if you keep trying to talk to them with it out.  They're also liable to smack you in the face if you keep trying to talk to them while they're in the middle of a firefight or on their way to complete their own objectives.\nThe ALife in this game can be buggy at times
column18: but that's because of the extra features added to the system since SoC.  Enemies can
column19: and will use grenades on you.  And they've all got their own pre-programmed cycles and tactical combat styles.  Some enemies will try to flank you
column20: while others will box you into a tight space with no escape.  Some may charge at you blindly
column21: while others will retreat to call in reinforcements.  A hungry mutant that spots you may follow you throughout the Zone until you either dispatch it
column22: or it dispatches you...while a less hungry mutant may just be protecting its territory and will leave you be once you leave its area.\nBut my favorite thing about the game is how it sets up the story for the STALKER universe.  This game is prequel to Shadow of Chernobyl
column23: and as such it tries to paint a picture of a more beautiful Zone; one that's still bustling with human interaction and chipper attitudes despite the hellish landscape they live in.  SoC is the opposite of this
column24: by the time it takes place the Zone is nearly lifeless and it really makes you feel empty and alone inside.  What makes Clear Sky so great though
column25: is the tragic ending of the game.  SoC has multiple endings
column26: but only two "true" endings...and of those two only one is cannon to the story.  But it's a happy ending overall.  In Clear Sky you don't get such a happy ending because it has to show you why the Zone is such a nightmare in the future to come.\nIn closing
column27: Clear Sky gets a lot of flak for being the weakest of the 3 games.  But it is not a weak game
column28: not by a long shot.  GSC Gameworld took some risks when they introduced Clear Sky because it changed the mold that Shadow of Chernobyl had set after so many years of being in development.  Overall
column29: I personally feel like it paid off.  I prefer the way NPCs interact with one another and the game world
column30: I love the rebalancing of artifacts and the methods of hunting them down
column31: and if you can get past the occasional hiccup or two due to shoddy programming...the experience is worth it."

reviewText:
A lot of people have rightly said that Clear Sky was disappointing after Shadow of Chernobyl. I agree, mostly because a lot of the maps are just reworkings from the first game. Also, there is a little less depth in the story, tipping the scale into Clear Sky being more of a straight shooter.

However, the 'factions' war element brings something genuinely new to the game. Moreover, all the great visuals are still there and, when the new maps come along from time to time, they are still a real treat! I like the changes that have been made to the artifacts 'system' as well - there are fewer of them to be had, and they are harder (and more dangerous) to acquire. This adds value to their value.

If you have an itch to replay Chernobyl, but perhaps don't want to play through the exact same game again, get Clear Sky, especially if its on offer. Clear Sky proivdes enough of a difference for you to get your STALKER fix!

People tell me that Pripyat is even better again... I'm saving it though!

reviewText: First I want to say that this game is extremely difficult, even on Stalker" (Normal). Near the end of the game you will not be able to purchase bandages or medkits
date: and trust me you will need them. If you run out of medkits you will have to turtle your way through massive and very cheap spawning enemies. Now I don't think this is a bad game
recommended: if it was intended to be hard then they nailed it. The problems I have with it are such:\n-Enemies have a hitbox inefficiency
hoursPlayed:
some enemies take massive amounts of ammo (1-2 clips) and others take a few shots even if they are the same. Don't bother aiming for the head it works on the lesser enemies.
-The game goes from a really decent RPG to a linear shooting gallery where you hind behind numerous walls and crates with a "hold" crouch which does not fit well.
-The ending of the game is something that unless you find out ahead of time you will never beat it. Unless you see that you need ungodly amounts of medkits and bandages "YOU WILL NOT WIN".
-There are bugs yes but sometimes freaking out and hitting the move keys enough you can get out. If not you better have saved recently.

Rather than being able to see artifacts, you need to find them with an anomalous activity tracker, which will track them with beeps. I strongly suggest getting to Yantar ASAP and upgrading that puppy to one that has a map attached to it.
I feel like there is more to do in this game than SoC, with the faction wars and such. But it does seem like there are less side-missions. That's kind of a con I suppose. Anyway:

This game has a lot of pros: The combat is interestingly difficult and forces you to think out your combat encounters, or have your entire carry weight taken up by medkits (Don't do that, that's a terrible idea). The faction system and faction wars are awesome. The upgrades are neat, the game is gorgeous, and blah blah blah.

On cons: This game suffers from pretty much the same issues that Shadow of Chernobyl did. Those are bugs, lots of bugs, the game tends to crash every so often (Quicksave! F5 is your friend. Do it often!), and... An issue I had with SoC that I still have with this game, is that it has an ABSURD difficulty spike in the last act of the game. I can't help but find it irritating. You have a set-up and souped up gear that has allowed you to breeze through everthing else, and then come the last act, you feel like you're wearing the leather hoodie you start off with, equipped with a... I don't know... BB gun.

Anyway, this game is an excellent game, it should be played.

reviewText:
Quick overall:

Play this game as what it is: an action/adventure FPS. This is NOT A RPG and this is NOT A SURVIVAL game. You just shoot things that appear in your way (and loot their corpses) in order to advance in the linear plot.

There's no moral decisions to be made, no different paths to follow, no interesting characters to know, no customization of the abilities of your character, no basic needs that you need to fulfill from time to time. It seems the developers kinda started shaping it into a RPG (big maps, side-missions, inventory system), but aborted the idea. If you deal with it as an action/adventure FPS, it's an OK game. Another thing: I played it with the Road to Limansk" mod

which corrects some bugs of the vanilla game and I recommend.

THE GOOD

reviewText:
Firstly S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Clear Sky is almost and exact clone of S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl with some small areas introduced and others removed. I see no problem with this as the story is different and compelling and the introduction of a weapon customization menu was a big step towards S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat where the game was perfected. However this eddition of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series has many less mods avaliable for it and there are many unbalanced aspects to the gameplay which are removed. If you have the money for all three S.T.A.L.K.E.R games get this!
As a veteran of the zone playing far upwards of my logged online hours i would recommend the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series in the following order:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat
S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl
S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Clear Sky
If you love a strong story i'd suggest S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl, but if, like me, you prefer maximized gameplay and a balanced combat system allowing you to aquire your favorite gun right away, then upgrade it to a monster as your progress i'd suggest S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat.

reviewText: Though by far the buggiest and often considered the worst of the STALKER games, the prequel Clear Sky is in its own right a good game, especially when paired with the Clear Sky Complete mod. Unlike Shadow of Chernobyl and Call of Pripyat, the various factions in the Zone have engaged in open warfare, and you can side with either the Bandits or the Loners, or Duty and Freedom, along with the titular Clear Sky faction. The main game areas comprise of much of the areas present in STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl, along with several new locations. New features introduced in Clear Sky include weapon upgrades and modifications, along with the faction wars feature.\nDo note that many players, myself included, consider the Clear Sky Complete mod almost mandatory to enjoy this game.\nNow get out of here, Stalker.

reviewText: Clear Sky is often considered the worst of the Stalker games, and it is difficult to disagree. However, that doesn’t mean that it is a bad game. In fact, it’s a great FPS/RPG. The atmosphere, the setting, and the characters are as unique as ever. The shooting mechanics feel great, and the artifact collection is very fun. Clear sky introduces the faction wars, with the player being able to join a faction and conquer territory. This is actually very fun, and I’ve spent many hours helping out my allies taking over enemy territory.\n\nAdd to this that the game costs $10 (or $2.50, when I bought it during a sale) and this becomes a no-brainer.
